title: Buffalo dancer
creator: Medina, Rafael
subject: Zia
description: A painting of a dancer in a headdress with buffalo horns. There are stylized clouds and lightning in the sky, two stylized birds and two ceramic pots. The pots are at the bottom of the image, one on each side of the dancer. The ceramic pot on the left is a bowl while the one on the right is a shouldered jar.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: image: 11 1/2 x 8 1/2 in.; framed: 18 1/4 x 15 1/4 in.

title: Morning hike in the Tetons
creator: Shaffer, Phillip
description: A sepia painting of a landscape. Aspen trees in the foreground frame a mountain peak in the background.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Four Seasons Gallery, Jackson, WY, September 21, 1987. Taped to the dust cover: "Sept. 21, 1987; 'Morning Hike In The Tentons'; 8X10 sepia watercolor; 'I tried to capture the suspense and the surprise that waits the hiker as he rounds the next bend in the trail.' Phillip Shafer; Jackson, Wyo."

title: Untitled (Four eagle dancers)
creator: Pena, Maria Antonia
subject: San Ildefonso
signature: Quah Ah Tonita Pena (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a Pueblo eagle dance. There are four dancers, consisting of two men and two women. The men are wearing traditional eagle costumes, and the women are wearing traditional white handwoven one-shoulder dresses with eagle feather headdresses. The dancers are in a group on the left side of the painting. The two in the foreground are facing right, while the two in the background are facing left. On the right side of the painting are two women facing left, each holding a bow and arrows. They appear to be singing. To their right are two drummers, facing left and wearing war bonnets. They each hold a drum in their left hand and drumstick in their right hand.
condition: repaired tear-upper left; creasing, water stains, white spots - top; dents and foxing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, who brought the paintings to their home, June 3, 1996. This painting was one of four purchased from Huston at this time. The others were by Mopope, Otis Polelonema, and Popovi Da.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cochiti Pueblo corn dance - The banner
creator: Pena, Maria Antonia
subject: San Ildefonso
signature: Quah Ah Tonita Pena (printed, lower right)
description: A painting, circa 1930, of a Pueblo Native American man dancing and carrying a decorated pole. His hair is worn in a Pueblo hairstyle and he is wearing a pink shirt, beaded and fringed buckskin leggings and beaded moccasins. He is also wearing a turquoise necklace and a silver-and-turquoise concho belt. On the back of the painting: "Cochiti Pueblo Corn Dance The Banner."
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail from Gallery 10 in Scottsdale, AZ, April 17, 1991. The painting was purchased by Gallery 10 from a Missouri couple, who had acquired the painting in the 1940s.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pueblo woman in ceremonial dress)
creator: Pena, Maria Antonia
subject: San Ildefonso
signature: Quah Ah Tonita Pena (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a Pueblo Native American dancer who is facing left. She is wearing a white, one-shoulder, handwoven, embroidered dress and a red-and-black handwoven sash around her waist. She is also wearing an eagle feather headdress and is holding two feathers in her right hand. Around her neck, she is wearing several turquoise necklaces.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Child dressed as a Koshare clown or Kossa)
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a child wearing a traditional Koshare headdress and black-and-white body paint. He is facing the viewer and wears a hand-woven breechclout, a hand-woven sash and high-topped dance moccasins. Above his head is a sun symbol and underneath him are geometric designs that include two turtles.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R.G. Munn auction held in Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of 15 purchased at the auction. The auction number, recorded on a tag on the back of the painting, was 585.

title: Mythical pony
creator: Pop Chalee
subject: Taos (Native American style)
signature: Pop Chalee over a feather (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a gold horse with a billowing white mane and tail. Its neck is arched, and its eye size is exaggerated.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Streets of Taos store in Santa Fe, NM, March 28, 1992. While visiting the store, the Zarrows noticed this painting hanging behind the cash register and asked if it was for sale. The woman guessed so and sold it to them. On the sale receipt: "'Pop Chalee Mythical Pony'; 1983 - 1989; 5 1/2" X 3 1/2"; original painting; tempera on French paper."

title: Fall scene - Victor barn
creator: Wilcox, Jim

title: Almost paradise (study)
creator: Spaulding, Don
description: A painting of two men riding horses and leading a packhorse as they are about to cross a stream. They are moving to the left. The man on the left is riding a paint horse and wearing an animal skin hat and fringed buckskin clothing. The man to his right is riding an Appaloosa and he is wearing a black wide-brimmed hat and buckskin clothing. He is looking backward over his left shoulder. The packhorse is following the second horse. Both men are carrying rifles. The trees in the background are gold and yellow.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, November 14, 1989. On the back of the painting: "Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow...; Exhibited in 'American Art In Miniature: 1989'; November 16 - December 18, 1989; Gilcrease Museum - Tulsa, OK; Study for 'Almost Paradise'; by Don Spaulding oil."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Chamita adobes
creator: Gonske, Walt
description: An impressionistic painting of three buildings. The dominant view is of the roofs. Two of the roofs appear to be tin, galvanized-metal roofs.

title: Pony songs
creator: Creepingbear, Mirac
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Pawnee (culture or style); Arapaho (culture or style)
description: A painting of overlapping images. On the left is a horse that has images of a buffalo herd overlapping its hindquarters. The herd appears to come from the upper right. Behind the buffalo herd and above the horse is the upper portion of a man's face facing the viewer. His hair streams away from his head and becomes part of the sky.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, March 21, 1992. This painting was originally purchased by Bob McCabe from Mirac Creepingbear in 1984. It was in his collection until 1992 when the Zarrows purchased it.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Winter landscape below Taos Mountain
creator: Gobel, Rod
description: An impressionistic painting of a winter landscape. In the foreground, the ground is covered with snow with some patches of earth showing. In the middle ground, there is a grove of trees with snow on them and in the distance, there is a snow-covered peak.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Total Arts Gallery, Taos, NM, May 13, 1980. This painting was one of three purchased. The other two paintings were by Walt Gonske. This painting was exhibited in Tulsans Collect, Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, OK, February 16-April 15, 1990. On the stretcher: "'Winter Landscape Below Taos Mountain'; 1978 Rod Gobel." The painting is stamped: Rod Gobel Studio.

subject: Otoe-Missouria (culture or style)

title: March storm - Truchas
creator: Fritzler, Gerald J.
description: A painting of a winter landscape. In the foreground, there is a hillside with patchy snow and a wire fence zigzagging across it. In the background, on the left, there are some buildings, with a figure in a red coat standing to the left of them. In the distance there are mountains with storm clouds above them.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance:

title: After buffalo meat
creator: Smith, Kevin Warren
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting done in a ledger drawing style that is depicting a Native American man in a top hat with a feather attached to top. He is carrying a peace pipe and pipe bag in his left hand and a collapsed umbrella that he is using as a cane in his right hand. He is leading a paint horse that is orange and white with a green tail.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, January 2, 1999. This painting was one of three purchased. The other two were by Murv Jacob and Norma Howard.

title: Pokoni tapushink ikbi (Grandma making baskets)
creator: Rutledge, C. A. (Catherine Ann)
subject: Choctaw (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of an elderly woman wearing a scarf over her hair as well as a calico dress with a white apron. She is seated on a blanket in a field and is facing the viewer. There is a double-woven, swam-cane basket with a lid on either side of her. The baskets are red, black and their natural colors.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 14th annual exhibition, Muskogee, OK, October 19, 1980, where this painting was exhibited. This painting was one of three purchased. The others were by Nadine Marler and Ruth Cole. On the label on the dust cover: "Artist: Catherine Rutledge; Title: 'Pokoni Tapushink Ikbi (Grandma Making Baskets).'" Also taped to the dust cover: 'Pokoni Tapushink Ikbi; (Grandma Making Baskets)'; Old Choctaw woman shown with a typical hamper type of basket, made of river cane which was split and dyed with natural dyes before weaving. Choctaws made a variety of baskets which were used for everything from storage to winnowing grain.; Catherine Rutledge."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Farmhouse and windmill)

description: A painting of a farmhouse and a small barn. Behind the house, there is a windmill and a water tank with hills behind them. In the foreground, on the right, there is a large tree. Also in the foreground are wildflowers and a trail leading to a red gate and the farmhouse.

title: Rim patterns
creator: Carpenter, Earl
description: A landscape painting of the Grand Canyon done in tones of blue and pink. Above the far canyon rim is a stormy sky. It appears to be early morning as there are shadows to the west and the clouds are pink.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Gallery of the West, Jackson, WY, September 23, 1987. On a sticker on the back of the frame: "'Rim Patterns' - Grand Canyon, AZ; 12 X 24; Location: South Rim (Brahma Temple) oil/pencil; ... Earl Carpenter."

title: Buffalo hunter
creator: Calle, Paul
description: A drawing of a long-haired Native American man wrapped in a buffalo skin. He is holding a decorated spear in his right hand and a buffalo skin shield with bird wings and feathers attached in his left hand. He is facing the viewer and looking to the left.

provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a wall sale at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, November 14, 1994. On the back of the drawing: "All reproduction rights retained by the artist" and the artist's signature.

title: Irrigation ditch
creator: Gonske, Walt
description: An impressionistic landscape depicting an irrigation ditch in the center foreground of the painting. In the middle ground, on the right, there is the suggestion of the figure of a man wearing a green shirt, a white cap and black pants. The trees and grasses are golden, which may indicate this painting takes place in the fall.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Total Arts Gallery, Taos, NM, May 12, 1990. In a letter in the artist's file: "Location of 'Irrigation Ditch' is El Prado, NM, close to Gonske's studio." On the card stapled to the frame: "Artist: - Walt Gonske; Title: 'Irrigation Ditch'; Size: - 18 X 16; Med - oil on canvas; ... #734." On the back of the canvas: "Gonske NAWA 'Irrigation Ditch' #734."

title: Untitled (Man on horse, facing left)
creator: Wieghorst, Olaf
description: A painting of a man on a light-orange horse, perhaps a Palomino, facing left. The man is wearing a cowboy hat, a yellow neck scarf, a blue shirt, chaps and spurs. His western-style saddle has tapaderos in place of wooden stirrups. Both the horse's head and his left forefoot are raised.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Stan Weiner, their son's father-in-law from New York City, NY. Mr. Weiner was also an art collector. He had four similar paintings by Wieghorst and sold the Zarrows two of them.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Man on horse, facing right)
creator: Wieghorst, Olaf
description: A painting of a man on a gold Palomino. They are facing right. The man is wearing a white cowboy hat, a yellow neck scarf, a blue shirt, and chaps. He is sitting slumped in a western-style saddle, which has tapaderos in place of wood stirrups. A rope is tied to the swells of his saddle. The horse has four white stockings and a white blaze that extends over its nostrils.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: War whistle
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of the head and shoulder of a Comanche man wearing a war bonnet and facing left. He has seven black stripes painted on the side of his face from his forehead to under his chin. He is blowing what appears to be a bone whistle. A shield with a bear painted on it is covering his left shoulder. The sky is stormy and a strong wind blows his hair and war bonnet to the right.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist, date unknown. On the back of the painting: "'War Whistle'; Comanche; 1977; Ralph Wall."

title: Preparing for the dance
creator: Forbis, Steve
description: A drawing of a young boy in an elaborate headdress facing the viewer. He is wearing four turquoise rings, two on each hand, a silver and turquoise bracelet on his right wrist, a silver and turquoise bow guard on his left wrist and a turquoise nugget necklace. His clothing consists of a multi-colored fringed kilt held up with a silver concho belt and high topped dance moccasins. There is a red, green and white hand-woven sash tucked through the concho belt.
condition: undamaged; drawing buckled in the middle
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via special order from the artist, Austin, TX, January 4, 1994. On a card glued to the dust cover: "'Preparing For The Dance' by Steve Forbis colored pencil, Image 15" X ? 4" Jan. 1995."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: image: 18 x 11 in.; framed: 24 1/2 x 17 1/8 in.

title: Sunrise at Crow Fair
creator: Forbis, Steve

title: Desba singer
creator: Morrow, Claudine
description: A head and shoulder portrait of a young Navajo girl. Her hair is pulled back in a chongo, which is the traditional Navajo hairstyle, and she is wearing a red blouse with a large turquoise-and-silver broach at the collar. She is facing the viewer and is looking to the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail from La Galeria, Sedona, AZ, June 4, 1979. On a trip to Sedona, AZ, they saw this painting in the La Galeria window, and when they returned home, they contacted the gallery about it. Subsequently, they purchased it. The gallery represented Ms. Morrow, and the painting came directly from her to the gallery to the Zarrows.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Hound's Tooth - Taos
creator: Gonske, Walt
description: An impressionistic landscape painting of a mountain with other mountains behind it. In the foreground, there is a river with trees in fall colors along its banks. The sky is full of clouds with a little blue sky showing.

title: Cooling off
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of two Native American men on horseback facing the viewer. The horses are side by side and standing in a stream. The horse on the left is brown and the horse on the right is white. The man on the white horse is wearing a horned headdress and has a bow and arrows in a quiver across his lower back, as well as a spear across the saddle in front of him. The man on the brown horse is wearing braids and has a rolled up blanket around his waist. The brown horse has feathers tied to his forelock.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via special order from Steve Seltzer and received May 22, 1982. On the back of the painting: "'Cooling Off' 1982."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

description: A painting of a bend in the Colorado River as it flows through the Grand Canyon, as seen from the rim. The sky is stormy but the sun has broken through to light up part of the rim and the opposite side of the canyon, on the right side of the painting.

title: Sun child
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of a Sioux woman sitting on a paint horse that is drinking water in the middle of a stream. A bay horse, with a travois strapped to it, is behind the first horse and is also drinking. The paint faces to the right and the bay to the left. The woman is holding a child in her arms and they are both wrapped in a tanned and beaded buffalo robe. It is a cloudy day.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Ralph Wall, New Braunfels, TX, June 1981. On the back of the painting: "'Sun Child' 1980 Ralph Wall." On the stretcher: "June 1981."

subject: Cochiti

title: Little sister
creator: Ballantyne, Carrie L.
description: A portrait of a brown-haired young girl with braids from the waist up. She is wearing a tan cowboy hat and a brown silk scarf wrapped around her throat. She also is wearing a cream knit shirt under a brown shirt with the sleeves rolled up and an olive-colored down vest. She is facing the viewer and wrapping her right braid around her right forefinger.

title: Horse thieves
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of a Native American man riding a white horse and moving to the right. The man is wearing a horned headdress and has a shield hanging on his back. In the crook of his left arm, he is holding a rifle and in his right hand, which hangs down, he is holding a quirt. A buffalo skin is hanging across the front of his saddle. Two more Native American riders are seen in the background herding horses.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Steve Seltzer, Great Falls, MT, September 16, 1977. On the dust cover: "Purchased direct from Steve Seltzer; 'The Horse Thieves'; acrylic 12" X 14"; 1977."

title: Hopi heritage
creator: Forbis, Steve
description: A three-quarter length portrait of a very young, black-haired, brown-eyed girl who is facing right. She is perhaps 3 or 4 years old. She is wearing a black sleeveless dress and a handwoven red, black, and green sash. Around her neck she is wearing six strands of heshi and turquoise necklaces that match her turquoise ear pendants. Her right hand is touching the necklaces and her left is touching her belt. Bird pottery designs are behind her in the lower third of the painting.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a wall sale at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, November 9, 1996. On the dust cover: "'Hopi Heritage' by Steve Forbis (Austin, Texas); Medium: Prismacolor; Miniature Art Show; Nov 9 1996; Gilcrease Museum."

description: A head and shoulder portrait of a Pawnee man with a roach hair cut. He is facing right. He has beads sewn to the edge of the bottom two-thirds of his ear. title: Welcoming committee
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of two white men being approached by several Native Americans on horseback with a tipi village in the background. There are three horses with the white men. Two are for riding while the other is a packhorse. One horse is grazing while its rider stands in front of it. This rider is wearing a fur hat and a capote tied at the waist with a piece of red fabric. He is holding a rifle in his left hand and the grazing horses' reins in his right. The other white man is sitting on a horse that is facing right. The man is looking over his right shoulder at the advancing Native Americans. The packhorse is behind the second horse.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail from Steve Seltzer, Great Falls, MT, August 16, 1977. On the stretcher: "'The Welcoming Committee' W S S."

title: Sun worshipper
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of a Native American man sitting on a horse, facing right, with a Native American village in the background. There are six tipis visible. The man is raising his arms with his palms outward. There is a quirt hanging from his right wrist and a shield hanging across his back behind his left shoulder. Lying across the back of his saddle, there is a bow and arrows in quivers. He is wearing red leggings and the horse is gray.

title: Untitled (Dancing kachina in green mask)
creator: Mootzka, Waldo
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of a dancing kachina figure wearing a green mask with a green ruff around his neck. He is wearing a handwoven embroidered kilt with a fox skin hanging from the back with its tail downward. He is holding a spruce bough in his left hand and a rattle in his right. He is facing right. His body is decorated with red and yellow paint.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Black Buffalo
creator: Lomayesva, Louis
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man facing the viewer and wearing a buffalo headdress and mask. His shirt is green with a red scarf hanging down the front. He is wearing a handwoven embroidered kilt, a handwoven rain sash, and fringed dance moccasins. In his right hand, he is holding a rattle and in his left, he is holding  a lightning symbol. His right foot is raised.

title: Straight dance
creator: Riddles, Leonard
subject: Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of a male dancer facing right. He is wearing a pillbox-shaped fur hat with a trailer that goes halfway down his back, a pink shirt, blue pants and a wide, beaded belt. He is also wearing a red breechclout and a yellow scarf around his neck. Under the scarf, on his back, is a trailer decorated with beads that reaches almost to the ground. On his feet, he is wearing beaded moccasins with tassels on the heel. In his left hand, he is holding a fan and in his right hand,  he is holding a decorated stick that he is using as a cane.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction held in Albuquerque, NM, February 6, 1999. On the dust cover: "'Straight Dance' Black Moon (Leonard Riddles); Comanche...."

title: Medicine man
creator: Roye, Burgess
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of the head and hands of a Native American man in braids. He is facing the viewer and there are beaded bands on his braids. His eyes are closed and his head is slightly bowed. His hands appear to reach out to a peyote bud at the bottom of the painting. There is a tipi behind his head on the right.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction in Albuquerque, NM, February 6, 1999. Taped to the top of the dust cover: "NAME Fred Beaver TRIBE Creek/Seminole, ... TITLE: Plains Indian Warrior, MEDIUM Gouache, ... NO. 803 EXHIBITOR NO. 124." Glued to the dust cover: "Saturday, 11/8/75, 'The Medicine Man' Speak thus of him who was truly the director of all matters; when illness came he was called, when war lingered in air and the chief's gathered he sat among them. All matters concerned was his also...in actuality his decision was final...thus, with his blessings his spirit would also, be a part of his blessings. Burgess Roye 11-7-75. Picture here, the medicine man blessing the coming in life and the part of life the peyote played among the Indian...again Burgess Roye."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Man dancing)
creator: O'Leary, Diane
subject: Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man dancing. He has long black hair that is flying in all directions and he is facing the viewer with his head turned to the right. He is wearing an orange shirt, a long blue breechclout, which is flying out to the left and right, purple leggings and purple moccasins with orange feathers attached to their heels. He is holding in his hands two round objects that are obscuring his hands that look like cymbals.

title: Ahula motif
creator: Dawakema
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: An abstract painting of a kachina figure done in shade of orange and brown. The kachina has a round face surrounded by feathers, which is painted on a raised area of the board. The kachina's shoulders are even with what appears to be ears. It is holding a staff in its right hand and its left hand is cupped as if holding something. The remainder of the painting is geometric designs.

title: Gathering wild onions
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a woman and two small children. The woman is facing the viewer and kneeling at the edge of a stream. She has a knife in her right hand and a basket full of onions to her left. A small girl, perhaps 2 or 3 years old, is standing to the right of the woman with her face tucked into the woman's shoulder. To the left of and slightly behind the woman, there is a little boy who is a toddler. The woman is smiling at someone across the stream and the little boy is gesturing to that person. In the background, there is a paint horse facing left that is grazing. There is a Native American woman's saddle on him and a travois is attached to the saddle. A dog is lying behind the horse, under the travois.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. This painting was one of 17 by Echohawk purchased at the time. On invoice: "... 'Gathering Wild Onions,' mini-painting; oil; art size: 4" X 6"; Painted in 1980."

title: Captain Jim, Pawnee scout
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A portrait of a Pawnee man from the waist up facing the viewer. He is wearing an elaborate, beaded, winged headdress with a blue bow in the center. There is a bear claw and bead collar around his neck. He is also wearing a blue shirt with a black tie. In his right hand, he is holding a tomahawk with a metal head and in his left hand, he is holding a feather fan.

title: Comanche dance
creator: P'otsunu
subject: San Juan (Rio Grande Pueblo)
description: A painting of six dancers facing left. There are three male dancers and three female dancers, and they are arranged every other gender, starting with a man on the left. Two of the men are wearing war bonnets and the third is wearing a roach headdress. The women are dressed in the traditional Pueblo one-shoulder, handwoven dresses with handwoven sashes, each one a different color. The women are also wearing capes and they are carrying arrows in each hand. The man on the far left is carrying a staff, the man in the middle is carrying a rattle and the man on the right is carrying a musical pipe.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 13, 1992. On an old dust cover: "Mrs. Montoya by (Potsunu) 1952; Purchased: from Liane Adams, Santa Fe, NM April 1956." From the original backing: "D.L. Rust...; 'The Comanche Dance'; Geronima Montoya San Juan." On the back of the painting: "'The Comanche Dance.'" On the gallery card: "'Ceremonial Figures' Artist: Geronima Montoya, San Juan; Medium: watercolor; Size: 4" X 7"; Number: A1599-001; P...; Dewey Galleries, Ltd."

title: Wild ones
creator: Tahoma, Quincy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Tahoma '47 with a vignette (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of six horses of various colors jumping over a log to the right while being chased by two men on horseback. One of the men is waving a blanket while the other is looking back and gesturing at someone else.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, January 11, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Kiowa dancers
creator: Williams, David Emmett (Tos-que)
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Tonkawa (culture or style); Apache (culture or style)
description: A painting of two identical dancers facing left. Each dancer is wearing an elaborate buffalo headdress with seven feathers attached. They are holding a bow in their raised right hand and a bundle of hair in their left hand, which is hanging down. They are also wearing beaded buckskin kilts with metal tinklers attached to the hem and dance moccasins with fur cuffs.
condition: some paint loss on the right dancer's face; acidic mats; cardboard backing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Belink's Studio, Santa Fe, NM, 1981. This painting was one of six purchased at the time. The other paintings were by T. Vigil, A. Blackowl, S. Mopope, Beatien Yazz, and Gary Montgomery.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Man of peace
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man facing left, wearing a blue turban and sitting under a tree. He has gray hair and is wearing wire frame glasses. His right arm is extended in front of him and a blue bird is sitting on his extended forefinger. The size of his right hand is slightly exaggerated. His left hand is resting on his knee. Another blue bird is sitting on a bush just behind his left shoulder.
condition: undamaged; acidic mats; foam core backing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Cherokee National Museum's Trail of Tears Art Show, Tahlequah, OK, June 15, 1991. On the backing: "Entry Five; Category: 1; Title: Man of Peace; Artist: Brooks Henson; Medium; Acrylic; ... 7/91 Tahlequah, Okla. Brooks Henson Native American Art (Cherokee)...."

title: Singers and dancers
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a group of people singing and dancing in a clearing in the woods. In the foreground on the right, a group of four people are singing. Three are facing left and one has their back to the viewer. In the middle ground on the left, a single man in a white shirt with his back to the viewer is holding a rattle in his right hand. Beyond him, on the right, four men in white shorts are dancing around a fire. Each one of the dancing men is holding a black staff.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, July 3, 1991. On old backing, attached to the dust cover: "'Singers and Cancers' by Brooks Henson; 7/91...."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Big Spotted Horse, Pawnee scout
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
signature: Echohawk (and an outline in red of a hawk) '96 (printed, L.R)
description: A portrait of a Pawnee man from the waist up with long wrapped braids. He is facing the viewer and wearing a blue shirt and a bone hair pipe breast plate decorated with German silver and beading. In the center of the breastplate is a triangular piece with a horse drawn on it. The man is holding a brass-headed tomahawk across his lap with both hands.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996. On tape on the stretcher: "Jack and Maxine Zarrow, Tulsa, OK; 7 1/2" X 9 1/2"; 'Big Spotted Horse, Pawnee Scout'; Brummett Echohawk 19 June 1996."

title: Untitled (Koshare coming out of a jar)
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a young-looking Koshare clown coming out of the neck of a ceramic jar which is decorated with a water serpent design. The jar has a fluted rim. There is a ladder leaning up against the back of the jar. The Koshare clown faces the viewer and appears to be waving with his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction in Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. The auction number for the painting was #690. On the backing: "18."

title: Mimbres polychrome man
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
signature: Tsa-sah-wee-eh and a spruce tree 1981 (printed, lower center)
description: A geometric painting with concentric circles filled with designs. The center contains the stylized figure of a man who has a round head and a square body. His arms are raised and his legs are spread. The predominant colors are metallic gold, brown, black and blue. The painting is done diagonally as though painted on a diamond.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, October, 18, 1991. On the backing: "'Mimbres Polychrome Man.'" On a sticker: "Authentic Native American Art Exhibition; Artist: Helen Hardin; Title: Mimbres Polychrome Man; Medium: acrylic; 4/14/81." On the invoice: "Purchased by seller from Helen Harden in 1981 at a show in Houston, TX."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Sioux war chief
creator: Pahsetopah, Loren
subject: Osage (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man in full ceremonial regalia riding a paint horse in the snow to the right. He is wearing a buffalo headdress with fully feathered trailers, bead-decorated buckskin clothing and fully beaded moccasins. He is holding the war bridle rein in his right hand along with a bead-decorated blanket. In his left hand, he is holding a fur-covered coup stick. The horse has feathers tied to both its forelock and its tail.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at Ruth's Turquoise, an art store in a strip shopping center, November 1, circa 1989. This painting was one of five or six by the Pahsetopah brothers, Paul and Loren, that the Zarrows purchased. The Zarrows gave two of these paintings to their children. On a piece of mat glued to the dust cover: "'Sioux War Chief' by Loren Pahsetopah Osage 80."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pueblo women singers)
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of 14 Pueblo women in three diagonal rows facing right.  They are dressed in the traditional one-shoulder handwoven dresses with lace-edged capes over their shoulders. Their dresses are tied at the waist with red, black, white and green handwoven sashes. Each woman has individual variations in the colors of her dress and cape, as well as the jewelry she wears. One woman, in the center foreground, is beating a drum which she holds, and the others are singing. There are cloud and sun symbols in the sky.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Dewey Galleries, Ltd., Santa Fe, NM, April, 16, 1991. This painting was one of two purchased at the time. The other painting was by Joe Herrera. On the back: "Dewey Galleries, Ltd. Gallery number AI C 342-1."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
signature: Tiger '65 over a feather (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a man in fringed buckskin clothing with a blanket wrapped around him, carrying a child in his arms as he climbs a snow-covered hill. He is facing right.

title: Hodos doodi (canary horse)
creator: Tsihnahjinnie, Andy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a paint horse running left while his Native American rider looks back over his left shoulder. The rider is holding a bow in his left and a fur-covered shield is resting on his back along with a quiver full of arrows. The man is wearing a red breechclout and has a scarf tied across his forehead. He is holding the reins of the war bridle in his right. Dust is billowing around the horse and the rider. The background is brown.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, March 7, 1991. On a sticker on the dust cover: "Given to Carolyn Marcia Heath 1979." Written on the back edge of the frame, top right corner: "79.137." On a piece of mat board glued to the dust cover: "'Hodos Doodi; Canary Horse.'" On the back of the Art Market business card glued to the dust cover: "Andy Tsinajinie 'Hodos Doodi (Canary Horse).'"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Abstract rainbird
creator: Velarde, Pablita
subject: Santa Clara
description: An abstract painting done in black, brown, gold, turquoise, and white. A spiral figure (this shape is commonly used by Pueblo artists to depict a parrot) is located on the lower left (viewer's quarter of the painting). Above it, also on the viewer's left, is a series of four ribbon like arching figures. In the center of the top is a half circle that has the appearance of a half sun. The viewer's right side of the painting is filled in with geometric and pottery design forms.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at Gallery 10, Scottsdale, AZ, December 1, 1990. This painting was one of four purchased at the time. The other paintings were by C. Bahnimptewa, Julian Martinez, and Gilbert Atencio. Supplied by Gallery 10 in a letter of authenticity: "Pablita Velarde, 'Abstract Rainbird.' Acrylic on illustration board. Ex. collection Mr. and Mrs. Humlicek, Phoenix, AZ." On the dust cover: "'Abstract Rainbird'; Pablita Velarde; Feb. 1991; Acrylic on illustration board; Ex. coll. Mr. and Mrs. Duane Humlicek, Phoenix, AZ. Purchased from Gallery 10, Inc. AZ (David Stock)."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Winter landscape, Cimarron iron bridge
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: An impressionistic landscape painting of a triple-arched iron bridge over a river. The trees are bare and the ground on both ends of the bridge is covered with snow. Tire tracks are showing in the snow on the bridge.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. This painting was one of 19 by Echohawk purchased at the time. From the artist's list: "This iron bridge is one of the last of its kind, standing across the Cimarron River northeast of Oilton, Oklahoma."

title: Harvest song
creator: Redbird, Robert, Sr.
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
signature: Robert Redbird Kiowa and a feather (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a man, facing right, who appears to be floating in the top half of the painting. He has long flowing hair and is wearing a wide-brimmed lavender hat, turquoise earrings and three strands of turquoise beads. He appears to be singing. Below the man there is a ceramic jar and six apples. This painting is an example of Redbird's airbrush technique.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from H. B. Belink of Belink's Studio, Santa Fe, NM. The purchase was made in Tulsa, OK, January 1, 1989.

creator: Vendramin, Loris
description: A painting of a Venetian canal. The canal is in the middle, with buildings up to its edge on both sides. There are two bridges over the canal: one in the foreground and one in the background. A rowboat is tied up at the right of the closest bridge.

title: If I were a tree
creator: Tye, Joe B.
description: A painting of a young boy. He is on the right side of the painting. His arms are outstretched, and his back is toward the viewer. He is looking at a multitrunk tree on the left, which is bare of leaves. In front of the boy is a plowed field with farm buildings in the background.
condition: undamaged; frame shows paint loss, scratches, etc.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX, March 26, 1980. title: Grandmother's attic
creator: Hughes, Stan
description: A painting of a little girl sitting on the floor in the middle of trunks, an old radio, a copper tub full of magazines, a suitcase, an antique electric fan, a wicker trunk and stacks of books. She is wearing a hat and dress that are too big for her and she is going through a black purse that is on the floor in front of her. She is sitting in the center at the bottom of the painting and is facing left. A pair of high heels is lying on the floor in front of the purse.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Big Horn Galleries, Aspen, CO, August 17, 1994.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Reunion
creator: McCarty Hessing, Valjean
subject: Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A painting of two women, two young girls and a toddler. In the foreground, an older woman is sitting on a tree stump and reaching out to the oldest girl who is reaching out to her as they greet each other. Behind the oldest girl, there is a slightly younger girl who has her right hand close to her mouth as she smiles. A young woman is standing behind the girls. She has a toddler on her back in a blanket that is tied around her.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 1981 Master Art Show, Muskogee, OK, September 20, 1981. The painting won the second place award at this art show. Taped to the dust cover: "Artist: Valjean McCarty Hessing; Title: 'Reunion'; Medium: Gouache; Artist's Tribe: Choctaw; 100% Strathmore rag board." On top of the entry form: "2nd Place Oct. 15, 1981 Five Civilized Tribes Master Show, Muskogee."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Night opening her cloak
creator: Harjo, Benjamin, Jr.
subject: Seminole; Shawnee (culture or style)
description: A round painting of a woman in a Seminole-style top and a long skirt. The woman is pulling back what appears to be the star-covered curtain of the night to reveal the day, which is on the left. The woman is facing right and looking over her right shoulder. She is pulling back the curtain with her right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, September 3, 1991. In addition to this painting. the Zarrows purchased three Helen Hardin etchings.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Venice
creator: Vendramin, Loris
description: A painting of Venice which includes the Grand Canal with St. Mark's Piazza in the background, the Doge's Palace and the Danieli Hotel in the foreground.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Loris Vendramin in St. Mark's Square, Venice, Italy, September 19, 1992. On the dust cover: "Venice - Purchased from the artist, Loris Vendramin in St. Marks Square, Italy - September 19, 1992. Pictured: Grand Canal with St. Mark's Piazza (background) and Doges Palace and Danieli Hotel (foreground)."

title: Slipping
creator: Tiger, Jerome
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
description: A painting of a young boy with a garden rake over his right shoulder, which he is holding in his right hand. His head is turned all the way to the right, while his body is only slightly turned. On his head, he is wearing a fedora-style hat with a feather stuck in it. His only articles of clothing are a pair of too-large pants that are in danger of falling down and a pair of shoes. His left hand is behind his back tugging at the back of the pants.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Linda Warren and her son, Anthony Warren, Oklahoma City, OK, May 30, 1996. On the dust cover: "This painting appears on page of the 'Life and Art of Jerome Tiger' book by Peggy Tiger and Molly Babcock. On May 30, 1996, Maxine and Jack Zarrow purchased this painting from Linda Warren and her son, Anthony Warren. Anthony's grandmother, Eloise Hall Warren, bought this painting from the Tiger family in 1966 or 1967. Eloise Warren grew up in Eufaula and spent her adult life in Oklahoma City."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Plains Indian dancers
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting, done on a tan background, of two Native American dancers dressed in powwow fancy war dance clothing. The clothing consists of two feathered bustles with one at the upper back and one at the lower back, a roach headdress with feathers, a breechclout with a beaded belt, beaded cuffs, a beaded head band and collar, beaded moccasins, and bands of bells just below the knees. The dancers face each other and each hold a dance fan in their left hand and a stick in their right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home, Checotah, OK, March 6, 1980.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Listening to the old man
creator: Henson, Brooks
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man and a boy sitting on a red blanket on the ground in the woods. They are facing each other and the man has his left hand extended toward the boy, who appears to be listening intently. The boy is wearing a blue-and-white-striped shirt and brown pants. The man is wearing fringed buckskin clothing and a red turban with two feathers attached.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, July 14, 1991. On the backing: "'Listening to the Old Man.'"

title: Warrior of the Plains
creator: Gray, Gina
subject: Osage (culture or style)
description: A painting of a three-quarter length portrait of a Native American man. He is facing the viewer and is wrapped in a blanket that is black on the right and red on the left. It has a blue star design on the black side. On his head, he is wearing a headdress with a single feather and around his neck he is wearing a bone hair pipe choker. On the left side of his face, he has four red stripes painted from his forehead to his chin. He is holding a shield decorated with feathers in his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, August 30, 1991. On the dust cover: "1991 'Warrior of the Plains' watercolor Gina Gray; Purchased from Indian Paintbrush, Siloam Springs, AR...."

title: William Pollack, Pawnee veteran of San Juan Hill
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
signature: Echohawk with hawk outline '96 (printed, lower center)
description: A portrait of the head and shoulders of a mustached man in a military uniform, more specifically the army uniform of 1898. He is facing left and wearing a gray wide-brimmed hat with crossed sabers pinned to the side of the crown. The uniform shirt is gray with the exception of a brown stand-up collar.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996. This painting was one of nine purchased from Echohawk at this time. On tape on the frame: "7 1/2 X 9 1/2, oil; William Pollock, 'Pawnee Veteran of San Juan Hill;' Raised American Flag - Spanish American War. Brummett Echohawk 19 June 1996." On the stretcher: "William Pollock, 'Pawnee Veteran of San Juan Hill' oil, June 1996."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

creator: Padilla, Fernando, Jr.
subject: Navajo (culture or style); San Felipe
description: A painting of a Pueblo building with people sitting on the upper roofs. There are corn, watermelon, bean and pepper plants growing in the foreground and a rainbow god is in the sky above the Pueblo.

title: Abstract apartment patterns
creator: Kirze, Yehiel
description: An abstract painting of irregular squares and black lines that give the appearance of windows. The painting uses the colors blue, pink, red, white and gold or cream, as well as black lines and circles.
condition: scratch on white area just left of center; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Forman, Maxine Zarrow's parents, from the artist at the artist's studio in Hifa, Israel. They were visiting Mr. Forman's niece, Sara, and her husband, Jacob Solomon, who took the Formans to visit the artist and see his work. Maxine Zarrow inherited the painting from her parents. For information on Yehiel Kirze: "Art In Israel" by Ron Shechori, Schocken Books, New York, 1976, pages 23 and 38.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Eagle Chief, Chief of the Pawnees
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
signature: Echohawk with hawk outline '96 (printed, lower left)
description: A portrait of a Pawnee man facing the viewer from the waist up. He is wearing a pillbox-shaped hat with a beak-like extension in the front that is pointing right. He is also wearing silver earrings that consist of a ring with three dangles, a bear claw and beads collar with decorated trailers and brass armbands. He is holding a brass-headed tomahawk in front of him with his right hand on the shaft and his left hand and forearm supporting the head. A peace medal is hanging on his chest below the bear claw collar.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996. This painting was one of nine purchased from Echohawk at the time. On the dust cover: "Brummett Echohawk, 19 June 1996 'Eagle Chief, Grand Chief of the Pawnees'; tempera, 5" X 7"."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Man Chief, Grand Chief of the Pawnees
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
signature: Echohawk with hawk outline '96 (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of a Pawnee man standing and facing right. He is wearing a feathered headdress with a long feathered trailer hanging down his back. His clothing consists of a red shirt, beaded buckskin pants and high-topped, bead-decorated, boot-style moccasins. His right arm is hanging down at his side.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, June 19, 1996. This painting was one of nine by Echohawk purchased at the time. On the dust cover: "Brummett Echohawk; tempera painting 'Man Chief,' Peta Lesharo - Pawnee Band Pechawrat (1 of four bands) Last Grand Chief of the Pawnee Indians, Lived in 1860s and 1870s."

title: Indian still life
creator: Buster, Garnet
description: A still life printing of a ceramic wedding vase and a bowl. The vase is on the right and is reddish while the bowl is on the left and is black. A multicolored string of glass beads is wrapped around the right neck of the wedding vase and is hanging across and off of the table. A silver squash-blossom necklace is draped inside the bowl and is hanging off of the table. Behind the pots, on either side, are ears of corn and two eagle feathers with their quills up.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Garnet Buster at the Country Osage Art Exhibit and Sale, Pawhuska, OK, June 20, 1981. This work is one of four purchased at this exhibition. Taped to the dust cover: "6/20/1981, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow; 'Indian Still Life' by Garnet Buster; 12 X 24; watercolor; ...."

title: Stickball players
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of two Native American men facing each other, each one holding two stickball sticks. They are wearing roach headdresses, fringed necklaces, and red-and-blue breechclouts. The man on the right has a decoration attached to his lower back that looks like a tail. They both have red paint around their eyes and three painted stripes wrapped around their forearms, thighs and calves.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Working hard
creator: Little Thunder, Merlin
subject: Southern Cheyenne
description: A painting of a man sitting on the ground with his back against a tree stump. He is wearing a cowboy hat with a feather in the hatband, a red neck scarf, a blue-and-red shirt, brown pants and cowboy boots. He is facing right. Behind him, an axe is also leaning against the stump. Sitting on the stump is half of a watermelon with a knife stuck in it.

title: Untitled (Fancy war dancer)
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek (culture or style); Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A hand-painted print of a powwow fancy war dancer wearing a roach headdress with three feathers, a lower-back bustle and feathers on his upper arms. In addition, he wears a beaded collar, beaded gauntlets, beaded wrist and ankle bands, a breechclout and beaded moccasins. The upper half of his face is painted red and his hair is braided and wrapped with fur. He holds a fan in his right hand and a flute in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Two women carrying water)
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two Pueblo women with large ceramic jars by a water source. The woman in the foreground is facing left and is approaching the water with a jar held in front of her. The woman in the background is facing right and is leaving the water source with her jar balanced on her head. Both women are dressed in a traditional hand-woven, one-shoulder dress, a small cape and dance boots.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, November 21, 1980.

title: Courting with flute ceremony
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a woman on the right sitting under a tree and stirring  a pot. She is on the far side of a campfire. Standing on the left, facing her, is a man playing a flute. He is wearing a red breechclout with a bead-decorated waistband and moccasins. Around his neck is a beaded choker which has a design matching his waistband and moccasins. In his hair, he is wearing a feather ornament. A river is running beside this scene and a setting sun or moon is in the background. The scenery is painted in blacks and grays.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Fred Beaver at his home, Checotah, OK, March 6, 1980. This painting was one of several purchased at the time. This painting was exhibited at the Gilcrease Museum's McCombs/Beaver Memorial Exhibition, Tulsa, OK, March 7 - April 19, 1981. On the dust cover: "Fred Beaver (1911 - 1980); 'Courting Flute Ceremony'; gouache; 1973; Collection: Maxine and Jack Zarrow."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Deer and fawn
creator: Nailor, Gerald
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a deer facing left with her ears laid back. In the foreground, there is a fawn facing right. The fawn's head overlaps with the deer's left shoulder. Behind the two deer are stylized plants and bushes and there is a Navajo Yei symbol in the sky. The painting is done in tones of brown and tan.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols of Santa Fe, NM, March 26, 1992. This painting was one of four purchased. The other paintings were by Pablita Velarde, Gene Kloss, and Geronima Montoya.

title: Young shepherd and pet goats
creator: Begay, Harrison
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Harrison Begay (lower right) Haskay Yahne Yah (lower left) (printed)
description: A painting of a young Navajo boy dressed in a red shirt and light blue pants as he moves to the right. He is wearing a turquoise-and-silver pin at the neck of his shirt, a turquoise-and-silver belt buckle, and a turquoise-and-silver button on his Apache-style moccasins. In his right hand, he is holding a coil of rope and in his left, he is holding the other end of the rope made into a throwing loop. Two kid goats gambol in front of him and behind him. There is rainbow Yei symbol in the sky over their heads.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Man with staff in snow storm)
creator: Tiger, Jerome
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
description: A painting of a man holding a staff in his left hand as he struggles through a snowstorm. He has a blanket around his shoulders which is billowing in the wind. The end of a red breechclout is blowing around his legs. He is facing left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Carol A. Bivins, Muskogee, OK, November 6, 1997. From a letter in artist's file: "...My father, James F. Perkins, purchased this painting in Muskogee, Oklahoma in 1966 or 1967. The first memory I have was going to Art Show of Mr. Tiger's in downtown Muskogee. I think it was Spring of '66. I believe this painting was bought in the fall of '66 or sometime in 1967. Sincerely, Carol A. Bivins."

title: Untitled (Profile of Native American man)
creator: Stroud, Virginia A.
subject: Cherokee (culture or style); Creek (culture or style)
signature: Virginia A Stroud 1973 G.G.G.S. (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a Native American man with long black hair who is facing left. The top half of the man's face is painted red and he has a feather ornament attached to the back of his head, with the feather sticking straight up. Another ornament is attached to his hair at the left side of his head. The painting, which is done on black mat board, is enclosed by a white line that forms a box with a bird drawn in the upper right corner.

creator: Taylor, Robert Lee

He is wearing a fur hat, a fringed buckskin shirt and a blanket wrapped around his legs.

title: Untitled (Pueblo drummer)
creator: Toledo, Jose Rey
subject: Jemez (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Pueblo man holding a large drum with his left hand as he raises his right hand, in which he is holding a drumstick, to strike it. He is wearing a blue shirt, a blanket kilt held up with a beaded belt, green pants and hard-soled moccasins. He has turquoise pendants hanging from his ears and a turquoise-and-heshie necklace around his neck. There are two bands of red on his face: one under his eye and one across his cheek, stretching from his nose to his hairline.

title: Within the knowledge
creator: Shoemaker, Ben Adair
subject: Quapaw (culture or style); Shawnee (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man's face surrounded by the figure of a water bird with its beak pointed toward the sky. The man's eyes are closed and his expression is peaceful. Immediately below the man's face is a peyote bud resting on a two-tone brown arch. Below the arch is a round object with what appears to be flames coming out of it. The bird and the man's face are bracketed by two tapered, red, ribbon-like objects, perhaps flames.

title: Stomp dance
creator: Jacob, Murv
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of 17 dancers, consisting of seven men, seven women, two girls and one boy. They are taking part in a stomp dance around a campfire in the middle of the woods at night. The women are wearing turtle shell rattles, or shakers, around their legs and the men are singing. The dancers are arranged by alternating genders with the exception of one girl who is dancing with an older woman, perhaps her mother.

title: Travelers
creator: Harvey, Nyla Jo
description: A painting of a man, a woman and a young girl dressed in the style of the early 1900s. The girl is holding a birdcage with a blue bird in it. The painting is very dark.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Nyla Jo Harvey Art Show, Tulsa, OK, May 25, 1979.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Dixie's rose
creator: Brown, Ben
description: A still life painting of two vases of flowers sitting on a table draped with a white tablecloth. On the right, there is a small peach-colored vase full of white daises. On the left, there is a larger blue vase full of white full-blown roses. Lying on the table between the vases is a red rose and a small bunch of white flowers.
