title: Tornado!
creator: McCarty Hessing, Valjean
subject: Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A painting of a black-haired woman facing right who is wrapped in a blanket and shawl. Her right arm is outstretched and her is mouth open as though in anger. Her feet are bare and while her left foot is firmly planted, her right foot, which is slightly behind her left, is off the ground. She is bent over and the blanket is swirling around her.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Masters Show, Muskogee, OK, September 20, 1981. The previous framer for this painting was B. B. Thompson, Muskogee, OK.

title: Winter's fire
creator: Fite, Frances M.
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a woman and a child in a snow storm with their backs to the viewer. The woman is carrying sticks on her back and guiding the child with her right hand. The child is carrying sticks in its arms.

title: Buffalo dancer
creator: Suina, Theodore
subject: Cochiti
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer facing the viewer. He is wearing a buffalo headdress with six feathers attached to the back, and a handwoven kilt and belt. There are metal tinklers attached to the bottom of his kilt and four bells around his waist. He is holding a rattle in his right hand and a bow in his left. His right arm is held out across his body.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Hansen Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 1991. On a note attached with a photograph of the painting: "Blumenschein Estate; 'Buffalo Dancer'; Suna, Theodore, Snow; Cochiti Pueblo. Estate Ernest L. Blumenschein (1874-1960). Left to his daughter, Helen Blumenschein (1909 - 1989). Her estate left to cousin - Santa Fe resident. Hansen Gallery acquired the painting 1980."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Living memories of a distant past
creator: Rutledge, C. A. (Catherine Ann)
subject: Choctaw (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a gray-haired man sitting on a log stool as he dreams of a stickball game. The man is facing right and sitting on the left side of the painting while his dream is in the upper right side of the painting. He is wearing a wide-brimmed hat, a white shirt and black pants. The man is resting his right hand on his right thigh and holding the handle of a stickball stick. He is resting his left hand on his left knee and holding a string that is attached to a stickball stick. Several more sticks are in a pile at his feet and it appears he has been making them.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's annual art exhibition, Muskogee, Oklahoma, October 19, 1980. Glued to the dust cover: "Artist: Cathy Rutledge; Title: 'Living Memories of a Distant Past'; Medium: oil; ... Artist's Tribe: Choctaw." On the exhibition label, glued to the dust cover: "'Living Memories of a Distant Past' by Cathy Rutledge (Choctaw); oil; ... Honorable Mention." Stapled to the back of the frame: Yellow Honorable Mention ribbon.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Deerslayer's dream
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
signature: Tsa . sah . wee . eh  with spruce tree drawing (printed, lower right)
description: A somewhat abstract etching of a man, almost a stick figure, with two shadows behind him. He is on the left and is facing the viewer. To the right of and behind him are petroglyph images of deer. Five are orange, three are brown and four are outlines. The man is holding a bow in his left hand and two arrows in his right. Behind the man is a series of circles and a horizontal zigzag line that goes from one edge of the etching to the other.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, September 3, 1991. On print documentation: "Printed 3/6/81 at El Cerro Graphics, Los Lunes, NM; William Boyson and Ricardo Ximenes printers."

title: Women at San Juan, women at the spring
creator: P'otsunu
subject: San Juan (Rio Grande Pueblo)
description: A painting of seven Pueblo women getting water from a spring. They are all dressed in the traditional one-shoulder dress, with a blouse under it and a long scarf or cape over their heads that hangs down almost to the hem of their dresses. The three women on the left have filled their ceramic jars and are carrying them on their heads as they head home. Behind the spring are two women who are waiting to fill their jars. To the right of the spring, one woman is kneeling and filling a jar and the other is standing behind her watching.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, NM, March 26, 1992.

title: Untitled (Man with blue hat)
creator: Biggoose, Marcellus "Mars"
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a man with long black hair (facing viewer's left) wearing a wide brimmed, smooth crowned blue hat. The hat has a beaded band with a feather attached. The man has a mauve colored blanket around his shoulders and his image stops there (upper half of the painting). A line curves downward from the front edge of his blanket and circles to the viewer's right. At this point the line changes to a brown band that seems to move away from the viewer. Two blanket wrapped figures (back to viewer) stand on the brown band as though waking down a trail.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Bountiful mother
creator: Hardin, Helen
subject: Santa Clara
signature: Tsa.sah.wee.eh with drawing of spruce tree (printed, lower right)
description: An etching of a figure shaped like an ear of corn wearing an elaborate tablita (headdress) with corn painted on it. The face is painted like a Pueblo ceremonial mask and in place of a husk the figure wears (like a cape) a hand-woven and embroidered blanket. The figure also wears high-topped dance boots. In the background is an embossed image of a Pueblo.
condition: poorly mounting; image rippled; conservation mounting; conservation glass
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Plains medicine man
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of two men sitting in front of a tipi. The man on the viewer's right is dressed in a "war" bonnet and beaded buckskin clothing and is smoking a ceremonial pipe. The man on the viewer's left is dressed in a breechclout and moccasins and is beating a drum. There is a campfire in the foreground and two horses are ground tied behind and to the left of the tipis. There are mesas and a big sun in the background.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Four dancers
creator: Pena, Maria Antonia
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of three Pueblo dancers (facing viewer's right) and a drummer (facing viewer's left). The furthest left dancer is a female holding a bow and arrows in her left hand and Spruce boughs in her right as she sings. In front of her is a female dressed in the traditional white hand-woven sleeveless dress ceremonial dress with a rain sash and dance boots. She holds feathers in her right hand that is raised up to her shoulder. In front of her is a man dressed in an Pueblo eagle costume. Facing the dancers is a man dressed in buckskin clothing, wearing a "war" bonnet who is beating a drum. In the lower right corner of the painting is a rain and lighting symbol.
condition: painting rippled; conservation mounting; conservation glass

title: Camouflage
creator: Joshua, Lee Roy
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
description: A painting of a Native American hunter kneeling on his right knee in some tall grass. He is facing the viewer but his head is turned to the left. He has a bow and a quiver of arrows on his back. An animal skin, perhaps buffalo hide hangs down around his elbows and across his back. The title, "Camouflage," is printed at the bottom of the painting.

title: Pause for thought
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a wooded snow scene with seven figures wrapped in blankets on the left side. There are two round objects in the sky, perhaps a sun and moon. The figure in the foreground is facing right and is holding a staff in his right hand. The other figures have their backs to the viewer. This is a painting of people on the Cherokee Trail of Tears.

title: Summer camp
creator: Bales, Jean
subject: Iowa
description: A painting of a Plains Native American camp with two tipis and multiple activities happening. It contains 12 women, eight men, three young girls, six young boys, one baby, five horses, two foals, five white dogs and five white puppies. The activities being performed include hanging meat to dry, teaching arrow making, gathering wood, cooking, tending horses, a hunter delivering meat and child tending.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Halsey Collection at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, January 1, 1992. On the dust cover: "Acquired from Halsey Collection 1/92; Gallup Ceremonial Award." Taped to the dust cover: "'Summer Camp' by Jean Bales won 1st place at Heard Museum rec's purple ribbon in 1977 at Phoenix, Ariz. Acquired from Jim and Menissa (Crumbo) Halsey Collection 1-92. Purple Ribbon; Heard Museum Arts and Crafts Exhibit 1977; Name: Jane E. Bales; Owner: 'Summer Camp'; Class: 1st Place; Date: 77; Judge: Heard Museum."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Native American man on horse)
creator: Seltzer, Steve
description: A painting of a Native American man sitting on a horse. The painting is done in the style of Olaf C. Seltzer, the artist's grandfather. The man and the horse face are both facing right. The man is holding a bow case across his lap and is wearing a shield on his left arm. He is wearing blue leggings and is sitting in an Native American-style saddle with a hide draped over it. The horse is a brown and white paint with two feathers tied to his forelock.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist at Joan Stauffer's home, Tulsa, OK, 1979. On the dust cover: "Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow; W S (Steve) Seltzer; June 1979."

title: Dance
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting done on gray mat board of the back view of a hoop dancer. He is wearing a roach headdress, upper- and lower-back bustles, a black breechclout, bells and long, goat-hair calf bands, and beaded moccasins. His image is painted in front of a blue circle and he appears to be dancing with two red hoops, held vertically. One hoop is circling his upper body while the other is circling his lower body. The title, "Dance," is written at the bottom edge of the painting.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Troy Anderson One-Man Show, Muskogee, OK, April 13, 1980. This painting was one of nineteen by Troy Anderson purchased at the time.

title: Four spirits
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting done on brown mat board of the faces of four men with long black hair. The faces are arranged one above the other and superimposed over a big brown circle and three smaller blue circles. The men's hair appears to be blowing to the right. The brown circle was created by air brushing with white paint and masking out the circle. The title, "Four Spirits," is written on the lower edge of the painting.

creator: Woodring, Carl
subject: Osage (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man and a woman holding a baby in a cradleboard. The man, who is facing the viewer and looking to the right, is dressed in traditional Osage clothing. This consists of a pillbox-shaped fur hat with beading and feathers, a breechclout, fringed buckskin pants decorated with beads and beaded moccasins. He is holding a string of beads in his left hand and a drawstring bag in his right hand. The woman, who is on the left and is facing right, has a shawl tied around her waist and is wearing beaded high-topped moccasins. There are paintings of buffalo with corn and bean plants on their backs in each corner.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow through correspondence with Tom Woodard of Woodard's Native American Art, Santa Fe, NM, December 5, 1992. Glued to the dust cover: "Artist: Carl Woodring; ... Town: Tulsa, OK; Title: 'Osage Child Naming Ceremony'...."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Two dancers)
creator: Dawakema
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of two identical stylized dancing figures. Each one is wearing a headdress with four feathers, a handwoven sash tied across his chest and around his waist, a kilt with a foxtail hanging down in back, leggings and moccasins. Each one is holding a rattle in his right hand and a bow in his left. They are facing right.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Fancy dancer
creator: Belindo, Dennis
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting on tan mat board of a powwow fancy war dancer. He faces right and is wearing a roach headdress, upper- and lower-back bustles, a red breechclout with a wide, beaded waist band, black tights or perhaps his legs are painted black, calf bands of bells and beaded moccasins. In his right hand he holds a feather fan and in his left, a blue stick. He is crouched as he lifts his left leg and reaches forward with his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, March 29, 1992. On the dust cover: "'Fancy Dancer'; tempera; 15" x 10.5"; museum mounted 3-18-92."

title: Masked Gods' revenge on Koshares
creator: Naha, Raymond
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting on gray mat board of four men dressed as kachinas chasing three men dressed as Koshares. There is a kiva in the background with a Koshare sticking his head out, and behind that there is a Pueblo. This scene takes place in the Pueblo's plaza area. One Koshare is being hit with a thrown watermelon, another is being chased with a snake, and another is being held down on the ground. His headdress has been pulled off by a Kokapeli Mana Kachina.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Dewey Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 13, 1992. On stickers on the backing: "#1 Title: 'The Masked Gods Revenge on Koshares'; Artist: Raymond Naha Hopi 1960; Medium: watercolor; Size: 32" X 40"; Number: A 1602-001. #2 Naha Raymond; 'Masked Gods Revenge on Koshares'; Number: 76; watercolor; 32" X 40"."

title: Arapahoe war dancers
creator: Sweezy, Carl
subject: Arapaho (culture or style)
description: A painting of six dancers and three drummers. The three drummers sit in a circle around a large drum in the center of the painting, with one in the back and one on each side. Each is holding a feather fan in their left hand and a drumstick in their right hand, which is raised to strike the drum. There are three dancers in a row on either side of the drummers. The dancers are wearing roach headdresses, feathered upper-arm bands, lower-back feather bustles, bands of bells on their calves, breechclouts and beaded moccasins. They are in various positions as they dance.
condition: some soiling; minor cracking along one side; bottom right side is loose
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, July 21, 1992. On a note found with the painting: "Artist: Carl Sweezy; Title: 'Arapahoe War Dancers'; Medium: oil on canvas; Circa: Early 1930's. The canvas used for this painting is off an old window shade. 'The Arapahoe Way', written by Althea Bass, is a book on the life story of Carl Sweezy. Ms. Bass lived in Norman, Oklahoma, until the age of 93. At this time, she sold her entire estate and moved to Washington D.C. to live with her only son. 'Arapahoe War Dancers' was in her collection. Approximately eight (8) years ago, this piece was purchased by the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery and sold to Mr. Robb Moore. Mr. Moore held this piece in his collection approximately four (4) years and decided to place it on the market with a number of other pieces. This painting was brought to the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery for consignment and remained in inventory until purchased by Jack Zarrow in 1992."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Dancer)
creator: Saul, C. Terry
subject: Choctaw (culture or style); Chickasaw (culture or style)
signature: C. Terry Saul O. U. - ASL
description: A painting of an abstract or stylized dancer facing left. He is wearing a breechclout-like garment that does not hang down. Attached to bands on his upper arms and calves are what appears to be a pair of butterfly wings. He is also holding winglike objects in his hands as he dances. His left leg is raised and his left arm swings forward with his motion.
condition: some discoloration along top edge; museum mounted

title: Kassa
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of an adult Kassa, or Koshare clown on the left, dancing and reaching toward a Kassa symbol in the sky. His body is painted in the traditional black-and-white stripes and he is wearing a traditional handwoven breechclout and facing right. To the right of him there is a ceramic jar with a young Kassa straddling it. In front of the jar is a basket full of corn. There are geometric designs both below the figures and in the upper left corner.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Robert F. Nichols, Santa Fe, NM, February 1, 1994. Nichols - Santa Fe, NM, Feb 1, 1994 #93.25 840; Picture 93.07 B #19."

title: Untitled (Three Native Americans on horses)
creator: Dick, Cecil
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of three Plains Native Americans on horses. They appear to be riding at a canter and are facing slightly left. The horse on the right is green, the middle horse is a gray and white paint and the horse on the left is olive-colored. The rider on the right is wearing a war bonnet and has a shield painted with a wolf head fastened to his left arm. The center rider has a shield painted with a buffalo head on his left arm and holds a staff decorated with feathers in his right hand. The rider on the left holds a bow in the air with his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, December 18, 1992. On the dust cover: "Untitled; tempera; about 1939; Cecil Dick, artist Cherokee Died 1992; 13 X 19." On a note in the artist's file: "This Cecil Dick painting was part of an Albuquerque collection that was sold in 1992. There was also an Alan Houser and an Archie Blackowl painting in the collection. The Houser and the Blackowl were dated '39 and '40. The collectors left written information that the three paintings were purchased at the Santa Fe Indian - Dunn school in 1939 and 1940. They indicated that this piece was 1939. Linda Greever 1/93 (the Art Market, Tulsa, OK) Cecil Dick, Artist Cherokee 13" X 19" untitled, circa 1939, tempera. Artist died in 1992. Property of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow...."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Oklahoma traditional dancer
creator: Jones, Ruthe Blalock
subject: Delaware; Shawnee (culture or style); Peoria
signature: Chu-lun-dit Ruthe Blalock Jones '80 (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of a traditional powwow dancer done on a blue background. He is facing left and is wearing a roach headdress, a bone hair pipe choker, a pink shirt, yellow pants with a blue breechclout, bands of bells around his calves, and blue moccasins. He is holding a feather fan in his right hand and a decorated wand in his left. This painting was used on the 1980-1982 Bacone College, Muskogee, OK, catalog.

title: Winter dance
creator: Vigil, Romando
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a man facing left and wearing a black hood with white dots on it. He is also wearing a red shirt, a buckskin kilt with metal tinklers along the hem, beaded yellow leggings and moccasins. The head of a deer is hanging down his back and he is wearing a quiver full of arrows on the back of his right shoulder. In his left hand, which is hanging at his side, he is holding a bow and in his right hand, he is holding a spruce bough that has badly faded due to sun exposure.

creator: Vigil, Thomas
subject: Tesuque
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer facing left. His lower face is painted black, his forearms and hands are painted blue and his upper body and lower legs are painted brown with white, zigzag, lightning designs. He is wearing an orange kilt with a snake painted on it and an animal skin is hanging down the back of the kilt. He is holding a rattle in his right hand and two feathers in his left hand. There is a black and yellow snake coiled in front of him.

title: Pueblo dancer
creator: Roybal, Jose D.
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer facing right. His upper body and lower legs are painted blue and he is dressed in a white handwoven embroidered kilt that is tied up with a rain sash. The skin of a fox is hanging down the back of the kilt. He is holding a rattle in his right hand and a spruce bough in his left hand. His right leg is bent at the knee and his foot raised as he dances.

title: Longhair Kachina
creator: Poseyesva, Raymond
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of a masked Pueblo man facing the viewer as he dances. His upper body is painted yellow and black and his lower legs are yellow.  He wears a white handwoven embroidered kilt that is held up with a rain sash. In addition, he is wearing handmade hard-soled boots, as well as a band of bells around his left calf. An animal skin is hanging down the back of the kilt, the tail of which is visible below the hem of the kilt. He is holding a rattle in his right hand and a spruce branch in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A painting of various petroglyph, kachina, plant and animal figures. There are nine kachina figures, 17 petroglyph images, four animals, and three plants. They are sprayed with multicolored dots.

title: Anasazi puberty ceremony
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A stylized painting of a young woman and four men wearing ceremonial priest dress. The young woman, who is in the center is lying on her back on a rug with her head to the right. Two of the priests are crouched, one behind the other, at her head and two are crouched at her feet. The priests are wearing elaborate headdresses and either kilts or breechclouts. The two closest to the young woman are holding decorated staffs in their left hands and rattles in their right hands.  The priest on the far right is holding a bow in his right hand and a tree branch in his left. The priest on the far left is holding a tomahawk in his right hand and two feathers in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Cheyenne spirit
creator: Tiger, Johnny, Jr.
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
description: A portrait of the head and shoulders of a Native American man facing the viewer. He has two feathers attached to a medallion on the right side of his head which are hanging down. He is wearing bone hair pipe choker at his throat. There is a red circle to the right and his head is in the center of two circles, one red and one yellow. Above him is the outline of a face facing upward that gives the effect of a mountain range.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Mudhead
creator: Velarde, Pablita
subject: Santa Clara
description: A painting of a Mudhead Kachina going up some steps. His body is facing the right, and his head is turned toward the viewer.  In addition to the Mudhead mask, he is wearing a black kilt, black wristbands and hard-soled dance boots.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

creator: Wall, Ralph

title: Koshare clown and dancer
creator: Da, Popovi
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Koshare, or kachina clown, as he approaches a ceremonial dancer. The clown is facing left, toward the dancer and is reaching toward him. The dancer is facing the viewer. The clown is painted with the traditional black-and-white stripes and he is wearing a traditional headdress. The dancer's upper body and lower legs are painted gray and he is wearing a traditional white handwoven embroidered kilt and a rain sash. He is holding a rattle in his right hand and some spruce branches in his left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, AZ, January 13, 1991. title: Ceremonial
creator: Asah, Spencer
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of three figures, consisting of two men and a woman, involved in a ceremony. The woman is standing on the left in the background and is facing slightly to the right. She is wearing a beaded and fringed buckskin dress and has a red shawl over her right arm. To her right, in the foreground, a man is kneeling on his left knee and beating a drum. He is dressed in a war bonnet, a red breechclout with a wide beaded belt, black beaded leggings and fully beaded moccasins. To his right and in the background, there is a man playing a Native American flute. His hair is braided and wrapped with fur and he is wearing a fringed breechclout and shirt, as well as red pants.
condition: staining; foxing; paint loss of the woman's face; conservation mounting; conservation glass
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Doris Littrell at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, July 21, 1992. The Zarrows purchased this painting via mail and phone conversations with Ms. Littrell. On a tag attached by a string: "Spencer Asah, 'Ceremonial'...." On the dust cover: "From the collection of Mr. Boren, President of South Western College, Weatherford, OK (1940 - 1950). Placed on consignment to Okla. Indian Art Gallery, 1991. Purchased from Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery in 1992 (Doris Littrell) Oklahoma City. Received from above in July 1992."

title: Untitled (Buffalo hunt accident)
creator: Yazz, Beatien
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man on a horse as the horse jumps over a buffalo bull that has just been speared. The buffalo is in the foreground with part of the spear in his right side. The buffalo is facing left. The man and the horse are in the air over the buffalo. They are facing right. The upper shaft of the spear is underneath them.
condition: scuffing on the buffalo; sun fading; staining; museum mounting

title: Dance of the Mountain Gods
creator: Williams, David Emmett (Tos-que)
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Tonkawa (culture or style); Apache (culture or style)
description: A painting of four Apache dancers consisting of three Gahn dancers and a clown. The three Gahn dancers have their upper bodies painted black, with a white star on both their front and back and white zigzags down their arms. Their faces are also painted black, and a red scarf is covering the lower portion of their faces. They are wearing three different headpieces, fringed buckskin kilts, bands of bells on their calves and Apache dance boots. They are each facing a different direction as they dance and whirl around. The clown's body is painted gray with a bull's eye in the center of his back. He is wearing a potato-sack kilt with a cowbell at the back and Apache boots. His head is covered with a sack mask.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow, circa April 1991. On the dust cover: "'Dance of the Mountain Gods' by David Williams, Sept. 21, 1980." Glued to the dust cover: "'Dance of the Mountain Gods.' This dance is a ceremonial dance being performed by the San Carlos Apache in Arizona. The dancers are to frighten away evil spirits during the young girl's puberty rites. While the girls are being attended to by their medicine man in a 4 - day ceremony, the 'fire dancers' dance all night long around a large fire. Their appearance and vocal sounds made have a fearful affect on the spectators. Sept. 21, 1980."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Comanche shield dancer
creator: Watchetaker, George Smith "Woogie"
subject: Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of three Native American dancers facing left and dancing in a single file line, painted on orange mat board. Each dancer is distinctly different, but all three are wearing body paint, lower-back feather bustles, breechclouts, bands of bells on their calves and dance moccasins. They are each holding a spear decorated with feathers in their right hand and a decorated shield in their left hand. The dancer on the far left is wearing a war bonnet and the other two dancers are wearing different versions of roach headdresses.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, January 1981. On a sticker on the dust cover: "'Shield Dance' by George 'Woogie' Watchetaker; tribe Comanche; 20" X 24" 1980 Tempera."

title: Untitled (Apache Gahn dancer #1)
creator: Palmer, Woodrow W.
subject: Miami (culture or style); Peoria
description: A painting of an Apache Gahn dancer facing right. He is wearing a black mask with an elaborate headpiece attached. The mask is fastened at his neck with a red scarf. Both the dancer's upper body and his arms are painted black with a white sawtooth design painted diagonally across his chest and white zigzag designs down his arms. He is wearing a yellow-fringed buckskin kilt with metal tinklers attached. A concha belt is holding up the kilt. He is also wearing hard-soled Apache boots. Red streamers are attached to his upper arms. He is holding a yellow knife-like objects in each hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, January 2, 1994. This painting is one of two by the artist purchased at the time. Both feature Apache Gahn dancers (see jmz.298).

title: Untitled (Apache Gahn dancer #2)
creator: Palmer, Woodrow W.
subject: Miami (culture or style); Peoria
description: A painting of an Apache Gahn dancer who is facing slightly to the left. He is wearing a black mask with an elaborate headpiece attached. The mask is fastened at his neck with a red scarf. Both the dancer's upper body and his arms are painted black with a white sawtooth design painted diagonally across his chest and white zigzag designs down his arms. He is wearing a yellow-fringed buckskin kilt with metal cones, or tinklers, attached. A concha belt is holding up the kilt and he is wearing hard-soled Apache boots. Red streamers are attached to his upper arms. The dancer is holding a yellow knife-like object in each hand.

title: Untitled (Dancer)
creator: Tsatoke, Monroe
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A print of a Native American dancer facing the viewer with his head turned to the left. He is wearing white paint on his face and body, a yellow-and-black roach headdress, a beaded choker, beaded bands across his chest, a wide beaded belt, beaded wrist guards, a black breechclout and beaded moccasins. He is holding a shield level with his head in his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Maxine Zarrow at a bank on 71st and Lewis, Tulsa, OK. The bank was closing and selling its art collection. This print is one of the silkscreen prints from the portfolio titled "Kiowa Indian Art" produced in France through the efforts of Dr. O. B. Jacobson of the University of Oklahoma Art Department in 1929. Taped to the dust cover: "We believe this is from the Monroe Tsoke (Kiowa) portfolio. It is a collector's item and [...] to look painted. There were approximately 300 to 350 of these prints produced in France. Printed to look painted; Monroe Tsoke Portfolio Kiowa (culture or style); Art printed in France; 300 - 325 printed."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Survivors
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: An abstract painting featuring superimposed images of three eagle heads, three men's faces in profile, two buffalo heads and one fox. They are painted on a rough textured background.

title: Untitled (Two Pueblo deer dancers)
creator: Vigil, Paul
subject: Tesuque
description: A painting of two deer dancers facing left. They are each wearing a headdress composed of deer antlers, spruce boughs and eagle feathers. They are also wearing white shirts, traditional embroidered kilts and rain sashes. They are each holding a rattle in their right hand and a staff decorated with eagle feathers in their left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Zuni warrior
creator: Dishta, Duane
subject: Zuni
description: A painting of a masked dancer facing right. He is wearing a mask that has a thick collar of brown feathers and a long tubular nose. He is also wearing a handwoven embroidered kilt and hard-soled buckskin boots that have a band of spruce branches around each ankle. There is a bracelet of spruce branches around his right wrist. He is holding a bundles of yucca leaves in both of his hands. A cloud formation is outlined behind him.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, AZ, January 1991. This painting was one of eleven purchased at the time from Gallery 10, Inc.

title: Pueblo dancer
creator: Martinez, Julian
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo dancer with long black hair who is facing left. His face is painted black and he is wearing a green shirt, a buckskin kilt and leggings with beading on the right leg and dance moccasins. There is a band across his chest with a tanned animal hide hanging from it, perhaps the skin of a deer. He is holding a bow in his left hand and a spruce branch in his right hand.
condition: light foxing; slight paint loss; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Hummingbird Kachina
creator: Bahnimptewa, Cliff
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
signature: By Cliff Bahnimptewa 73 2/ Kiva drawing (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a dancing kachina wearing a mask and facing the viewer. His mask has a long, black, pointed beak, a green face, red "ears" and feathers on top. In addition, it has a ruff or collar of spruce branches. The dancer also has numerous green, yellow and red circles painted on his body. He is wearing straps across, a breechclout held up with a red, green and black handwoven belt, bands of bells around his calves and hard-soled dance boots. His head is cocked slightly to the left and his left arm is raised at shoulder height.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, AZ, December 1, 1990. title: Night dance
creator: David, Neil
subject: Hopi-Tewa (culture or style)
description: A painting on a black background of eight kachinas and two men at the entrance to a kiva. There are two Mana Kachinas, who are female, and six Longhair Kachinas. All of the kachinas are wearing traditional masks. One of the Longhair Kachinas is descending the Kiva ladder and another is preparing to follow him. An elder wrapped in a blanket is standing to the right of the kiva while another man stands beside him holding a kerosene lantern.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market's Sale of Important Art, Tulsa, OK, April 14, 1991. On a sticker on the dust cover: "Property of Carolyn Heath loaned to Pueblo Petroleum Co."

subject: San Ildefonso

They are each holding a rattle in their right hand and a spruce branch in their left hand.

title: Straight dancer
creator: Blackowl, Archie
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow straight dancer. He is facing left with his back slightly to the viewer. He is wearing a roach headdress, a gold shirt, a long trailer with silver conchas hanging down his back, a red breechclout, blue trousers with a strip of beading down the sides, a double row of bells around each upper calf and beaded moccasins. He is holding a feather fan in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Prime rider
creator: Abeyta, Narciso
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A non-realistic painting of a woman in a full, gathered, blue-and-green skirt riding a paint horse without a saddle. The woman and the horse are facing left. The horse appears to be rearing as the woman strikes him with a quirt, which she is holding above her head in her right hand. She is holding the single rein in her left hand. On the horse's left flank, there appears to be a brand: NA.
condition: some soiling along the top edge and lower left side; frame separating at the upper corners
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Green corn ceremonial
creator: White Deer, Waylon Gary
subject: Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A painting of 13 figures dancing around a campfire on the right side of the painting. On the left side, partially superimposed over the dance scene is an ear of multi-colored flint corn and the heads of a man and a woman. The man is wearing a red turban and the woman's head is silhouetted against a moon.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Southern Plains fancy dancer
creator: Geionety, Ron W.
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A drawing of a fancy war dancer done predominately in red. The dancer is facing the viewer and is looking to the right. He is wearing a feather headdress, upper- and lower-back feather bustles, a beaded and fringed cape across his shoulders, a bone hair pipe breastplate, a decorated blue breechclout, bands of bells just below his knees, beaded bow guards on his wrists, and beaded moccasins. He is holding a spear over his head in his right hand. In his left hand, he is holding a feather fan at his side. His left leg is bent and raised at hip height.
condition: painting rippled; conservation mounting; conservation glass
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Ron Geionety at the Tallasi Winter Festival, Tulsa, OK, December 3, 1993. Written on the backing: "'Southern Plains Fancy Dancer'; Ron W. Geionety 12/3/93." Glued to the backing is a brief biographical sketch.

title: Stickers
creator: Stroud, Virginia A.
subject: Cherokee (culture or style); Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of four young women, a little girl and a young man. The young man is sitting down taking stickers out of his foot. The little girl is on the left, crying and reaching upwards in order to be picked up. One of the young women is reaching back toward her. On the right, two other young women hang onto a third woman as they remove stickers from their feet.

The horse's hooves are all off the ground as he runs.

title: Leaving for the spring buffalo hunt
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American hunting party consisting of eight men on horses. They are crossing a stream as they leave camp. They are smiling as they move toward the viewer and slightly to the left. In the background there are three tipis and people waving. The light indicates it is early in the morning.
condition: crazing in the sky; paint loss; acidic mats; cardboard backing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. On a card glued to the dust cover: "'Leaving for the Spring Buffalo Hunt' 1976." Data from the artist: "'Morning Hunt or River Crossing (Leaving for the Spring Buffalo Hunt)'; Tempera; Art size: 8" x 14"; date painted: 1976; This depicts the spirit of an early spring hunt. Both men and horses are glad to get out of camp. Anticipating a good hunt, the men laugh and talk. Children follow the hunters out of the village. Fed by melting snow, the stream ripples with new life. A Killdeer in the foreground is looking for a nesting spot as daylight breaks in the east."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Flute song
creator: Pahsetopah, Loren
subject: Osage (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Plains Native American man silhouetted against the moon as he plays a flute for the young woman sitting at his feet. The scene is painted against a black background. The man, who is standing and facing left, is wearing a war bonnet, a bone hair pipe choker, a red breechclout, and fringed and beaded buckskin leggings. The woman, who is sitting on a buffalo hide spread on a rack, is wearing a fringed and beaded buckskin dress, a bone hair pipe choker and breastplate and fully beaded boots. She is holding a beaded feather fan in her hands, which are resting in her lap.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Eagle Dancers - J Secatero (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of two Pueblo eagle dancers. They are facing each other in the center of the painting. They are wearing eagle masks, feathered arm ornaments made to look like wings, handwoven embroidered kilts and handwoven belts. Behind the dancers, there is a wood ladder that is leaning up against a Pueblo wall. The dance appears to be taking place in the Pueblo's plaza area.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: When the underwater people talked
creator: Wall, Ralph
description: A painting of two Plains Native Americans beside a body of water. There are two men in the foreground. The one on the left is on his hands and knees looking at a disturbance in the water. The second man, who is wearing a horned headdress, is standing in a slightly crouched position at the first man's left shoulder. The second man is holding a peace pipe in his left hand while he covers his mouth with his right hand. His shoulders are painted green and he has both a bow and an arrow quiver across his back. In the background, there are three Native American men on horseback and two riderless horses.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via special order from Ralph Wall, New Braunfels, TX, May 8, 1980. On a brass plaque: "'When the Underwater People Talked'; Ralph Wall." On the back of the painting: "'When the Underwater People Talked' 1979, Ralph Wall."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
frame: Wood (plant material); Antiquing; Trimming (decorative material); Silver (color)

title: Oil and the Osage
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of an oil well in the right background blowing out, scaring two horses that are pulling a wagon with a man, woman and child in it. The horses are bolting to the left while the man is trying to control them and the woman and child are hanging on for dear life. A small dog is running in the foreground.
condition: undamaged; acidic mats; cardboard backing; painting has shifted
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via special order from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. Data from the artist: "Tempera; Art size: 7" X 12"; Date painted: 1979; This depicts an Osage family in their wagon, going to town, just as a well comes in, frightening the horses. Taped to the dust cover: "Echohawk Artist... 'Oil and the Osage.'"

title: Noon chuck wagon or the smell of beef and beans
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
signature: Echohawk with outline of hawk 1983 (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of a chuck wagon under a tarp shelter on the left, carrying six men who are either sitting or standing as they eat, while two cowboys on horses ride toward the viewer on the right. In the distant background, there is a herd of cattle. On the far right of the painting there is a corral. Behind the riders, there are some saddled horses, believed to be the cowboys' remuda.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 24, 1991. On a brass plaque: "'The Smell of Beef and Beans' by Brummett Echohawk." Glued to the dust cover: "'Noon Chuck Wagon' or 'The Smell of Beef and Beans'; Echohawk with an outline of a hawk; 1983, Tempera painting; To Jack and Maxine Brummett Echohawk 24 July, 1991."

description: A portrait of a Native American dancer from the waist up who is facing left. title: Two step
creator: Blackowl, Archie
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of an Native American man and woman, both dressed in powwow finery, dancing side by side while holding hands. They are facing the viewer. The man is dressed in a roach headdress, a beaded shoulder cape, upper- and lower-back feather bustles, a red breechclout with a beaded belt, beaded armbands, beaded wrist bow guards, bands of bells around his calves and beaded moccasins. The woman is wearing a beaded white buckskin dress, a long bone hair pipe breastplate and beaded dance boots. She has a drawstring bag hanging on her left forearm.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, August 30, 1991.

title: Southern Plains fancy dancer
creator: Geionety, Ron W.
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow fancy war dancer done predominantly in yellow. He is facing the viewer with his head turned to the left and looking toward the ground. He is wearing the traditional upper- and lower-back feather bustles, a roach headdress, and a breechclout. He is holding beaded and feathered fans in both hands. His left hand is raised over his head and his right hand is lowered, close to his right knee. His left knee is at waist height, with the foot crossed over his right knee.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Ron Geionety at the Tallasi Winter Festival, Tulsa, OK, December 3, 1993. On the cardboard backing: "'Southern Plains Fancy Dancer'; 12-3-93 Ron W. Geionety 125."

title: Tail dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Crumbo (printed, lower right), Woody Crumbo (script, lower right)
description: A silkscreen of a war dancer performing a portion of a dance called The Tail Dance. His feet and knees are pointing toward the left, while his upper torso is facing the viewer and his head is turned to the right. Both of his knees are bent. His left knee is raised at waist height and his right foot is on the ground. Most of his body, excluding his face and hands, is painted black with red, yellow and gray designs. His face is painted red and white. He is wearing a roach headdress, feathered rosettes on his upper arms, a lower-back feather bustle, a red breechclout, ankle bells and beaded moccasins. A scalp is hanging from his belt. In his right hand, he is holding a feather and in his left hand, he is holding a feather fan.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a store in Springdale, AR.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Tail dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Crumbo (printed, lower right), Woody Crumbo (script, lower right)
description: A print of a war dancer performing a portion of a dance called The Tail Dance. His feet and knees are pointing toward the left, while his upper torso is facing the viewer and his head is turned to the right. Both of his knees are bent. His left knee is raised at waist height and his right foot is on the ground. Most of his body, excluding his face and hands, is painted black with red, yellow and gray designs. His face is painted red and white. He is wearing a roach headdress, feathered rosettes on his upper arms, a lower-back feather bustle, a red breechclout, ankle bells and beaded moccasins. A scalp is hanging from his belt. In his right hand, he is holding a feather and in his left hand, he is holding a feather fan.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Last sunset
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
description: A print of a gray-haired Native American man sitting on a rock, looking at a broken bow that he is holding in his right hand. He is facing left and has a buffalo robe wrapped around his hips. His old horse is standing behind him with his head hung. There is a Native American saddle on the horse that has a decorated shield hanging from it. There are two vultures just beyond the horse. The sun is setting in the distance.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum Gift Shop, Tulsa, OK, November 11, 1991. On the dust cover: "#1116" and biographical data about the artist.

title: Feather dance
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Crumbo (printed, lower right), Woody Crumbo (script, lower right)
description: A print of a Plains Native American dancer in an elaborate costume. His head is turned to the right and his legs are turned to the left. He is wearing a roach headdress, feathered rosettes on his upper arms and lower legs, a feathered tail bustle and a red breechclout with a beaded belt. His body is painted blue with cream, gray and red designs. He is holding a fan in his right hand and a flute in his left hand. He is also wearing numerous other beaded ornaments.

title: Untitled (Eagle dancer)
creator: Tsatoke, Monroe
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man wearing an eagle costume as he dances. He is facing slightly to the right. He is wearing an eagle headdress, feathered arm decorations, a feathered tail bustle, a yellow kilt with a red zigzag design near the hem, bands of bells around his calves, goat-hair ankle bands and beaded moccasins. He has red and turquoise paint on his eyes and cheeks and he is wearing a silver medallion around his neck. He has a straw-like whistle in his mouth.

title: War dancer
creator: Mopope, Stephen
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man dancing a fancy war dance. He is facing the viewer with his head turned slightly to the right. He is wearing a roach headdress, feathered arm rosettes, a tail bustle, a blue breechclout with a beaded belt, a vest-like garment with beaded medallions, bands of bells around his calves, goat-hair ankle bands and beaded moccasins. His left leg is raised behind him and bent at the knee and his arms swing as he dances.
condition: spot by right hand; scratch on right leg; conservation mounting; conservation glass

title: Wedding ceremony
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek (culture or style); Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man and woman standing in front of a tree. They are facing the viewer. The woman is on the left and slightly in front of the man. The woman is wearing a yellow, fringed and beaded buckskin dress along with fully beaded boots. She is holding a beaded feather fan in her left hand. The man is wearing a three-feather headdress, a blue bead choker, a band across his chest that holds a bow and arrow quiver, a blue breechclout, bead-decorated buckskin leggings and beaded moccasins. His face and arms are decorated with paint designs.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: First rain call by a young rain priest of Zuni
creator: Sandy, Percy Tsisete
subject: Zuni
description: A painting of two ceremonial figures. The figure on the left is dancing and holding out two feathers toward stylized clouds. He is facing right and wearing a sash and a kilt that are both hand-woven and embroidered. The figure on the right is facing left. He is blowing on a long flute or pipe that is pointed toward what appears to be a spring. He is wrapped in an embroidered blanket and is wearing leather leggings.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Hansen Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 25, 1991. The painting was from the estate of Ernest Blumenshein (1874-1960). At his death, his daughter, Helen Blumenshein (1909-1989) inherited it. At her death, it went to a cousin who lived in Santa Fe and was then purchased from her by the Hansen Gallery in 1990.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ready to dance
creator: Atencio, Gilbert Benjamin
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a man dressed as a Koshare, or Clown Kachina as he prepares to take part in a ceremony. His body is decorated with the traditional black-and-white stripes and face paint. His hair is tied in two ponytails, one on either side of his head, and he is wearing a handwoven breechclout. He is holding spruce boughs in his right hand. He is slightly crouched and his hands are held out in front of him as he starts to dance.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow through correspondence with Gallery 10, Inc., Scottsdale, AZ, December 1, 1990. Data provided by Gallery 10, Inc.: "EX. title: Untitled (Man in wheelchair)
creator: Rockwell, Norman
description: A reproduction of a painting depicting a proud-looking man wearing bib overalls and rolling his wheelchair to the right. The man is holding a yellow lunch box on his lap and a check from Goodwill Industries in his left hand as he maneuvers his wheelchair with his right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Gifted to Jack Zarrow in appreciation of his efforts on behalf of the Capitol Fund Drive for Goodwill Industries, Tulsa, OK, May 19, 1994. Peggy Helmerich also received the same print for her efforts as co-chairman. Below the print: "This print is from the original Norman Rockwell painting presented to the Pittsfield, Massachusetts Goodwill in 1958, which now hangs in the Goodwill Industries International Offices in Bethesda, Maryland. It expresses the jubilation felt by people with disabilities when they earn a wage in the workforce and has become a symbol of Goodwill Accomplishments."

title: Independence Day in Ghana
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a closely-grouped crowd of people. A man on the left is carrying a green flag. To the right of him, there is a man shooting a gun into the air. To his right, there is a man playing a flute-like instrument. The people behind them aren't distinct, only suggested.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow in Accra, Ghana, Africa, January 2, 1978. Mr. Zarrow wanted some paintings of the Ghanaian culture, and his friend, Bill St. Johns, acquired four paintings by A. O. Bartimeus for him. Mr. Zarrow later learned that A. O. Bartimeus was one of the leading artists in Ghana.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Mourning party
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a group of women under a tent-like structure in the middle of some buildings, perhaps a city street. There are 10 figures. Slightly to the left of center, there is a woman dressed in blue being supported by two other women. On the right, there are three seated women. One woman, dressed in blue, has her head bowed.

title: Seminole mother
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a woman in traditional Seminole dress sitting under a tree. The woman is in the foreground and facing the left. In the background, from left to right, there is a dog laying down, two young men playing a stick game, and a young girl. Behind them all is a Seminole village.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist, May 16, 1980. On a On a sticker on the dust cover: "Fred Beaver (1911-1980); 'Seminole Mother'; gouache; 1980; collection Maxine and Jack Zarrow."

title: Avenue of trees (Bourre Gardens)
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a road or path with a row of trees on both sides whose branches meet overhead. In the upper right, a city can be seen. Two people with their backs to viewer are walking down the road. It is a painting of an area of the Bourre Gardens.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Ball of wisdom
creator: Bartimeus, Albert Osabu
description: An impressionistic painting of a gathering of around 15 people. On the left, there is a man holding a large, round, ceramic vessel with a red rope around it. In the center foreground, there is a man wearing green pants with his back to the viewer. On the right, there is a man with a drum hanging from his shoulder by a red strap. Everyone is barefoot.
condition: chipped paint on the lower right edge

title: Untitled (African market scene #1)
creator: Krotei-Tetteh, Emmanuel
description: A drawing of women in an African outdoor market. In the center of the drawing are two women with large baskets balanced on their heads. The woman on the left is facing right and the woman on the right has her back to the viewer as she walks away. The woman on the right is supporting her basket with her right hand. They are both wearing thong sandals on their feet.

creator: Krotei-Tetteh, Emmanuel
description: A drawing of women in an African outdoor market. In the foreground, there is a woman seated behind the produce she is selling. To the right of her, there is another woman standing behind her produce display. In the left middle ground, there are two women about to pick up a large basket. Beyond them, there is a woman with an infant tied to her back and other women standing with baskets balanced on their heads.

title: Green corn dance
creator: Weddle, Glenda Starrlene (Star) Tehee
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)

provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at an Allard Auction held in Santa Fe, NM, to benefit the Institute of American Indian Arts scholarship fund, December, 1990. title: Lung shot #3
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A drawing of a Native American man riding a brown-and-white paint horse at a full run as he shoots an arrow into the right side of a running buffalo bull. The rider and the bull are both running to the right.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's first unofficial Rendezvous exhibition, June 14, 1979. Brummett Echohawk was one of two "Quick draw" artists to give an exhibition of their art. The drawing was then auctioned, and Mr. Zarrow was the successful bidder. On the dust cover: "1st Gilcrease Rendezvous, June 14, 1975; Quick Draw." Taped to the dust cover: "6/14/79 Pawnee Indian Rider; Pawnee Buffalo hunter 'Lung Shot 3.'"

title: As one
creator: Roye, Burgess
subject: Ponca
description: A painting of two faces, one a man and one a woman, facing left. The woman's face is in front of the man's and overlaps the back of his head. The man is wearing two feathers in his hair. These heads seem to float in space over a Plains Native American tipi. Their long hair flows downward and connects with the tipi. This painting was done on an orange mat board.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, OK, October 31, 1980. The Gentry Gallery and the McDonnell Douglas Tulsa Management Club held this exhibition as a fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program's scholarship fund. Taped to the dust cover: "As one; in the image of oneness we have become; in thought of our dream as together we are to become its truth...as the rain joins the dried earth and brings it coolness; as the wind brings forth a seed to become as a witness to our lives' greatest journey through lovingness that we might grow with all our truths as one. burgess roye"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
frame: Wood (plant material); Brown (color); Grain patterns; Cream (color)

title: James Bigheart
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A portrait of the head and shoulders of a man whose black hair is of medium length and is cut straight across in line with his jaw. He is wearing a black suit coat, a blue-and-white bow tie and a vest. The vest has a design of yellow medallions edged with red and blue against a black background.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. On the stretcher: "James Bigheart 1838 - 1908; Full blood Osage; Born in St Paul, Kansas, then an Osage village. Buried near now Barnsdall, Okla. (previously Bigheart, Okla.) Chief James Bigheart - led in organizing the Osage Nation under a written constitution. Pun-kah-wi-tah-An-Kah Known as 'Big Jim' called 'Moses of the Osages' for his role in preserving the mineral rights in common for the 2229 tribal members. First elected principal Chief in 1882 - Osage Nation comprises 1,476,539 acres. Served his people as their leader or Chief from 1875-1900. Negotiated and signed the first blanket oil and gas sale in 1896 - Fathered the 'headright' system. 14"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: image: 24 x 18 in.; framed: 31 7/8 x 25 7/8 in.

title: Trader on rock
creator: Fife, Jimmie Carole
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man wearing a gray head wrap standing with his left foot on a rock. He is facing the viewer with his hands spread as though explaining something. He is wearing pantaloons with green printed garters and a long tan shirt with pink ruffles at the hem, cuffs and shoulder seams. The strap of a beaded blue bandoleer bag is hanging across his chest, while the bag is resting on his right hip.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, OK, October 31, 1980. The gallery and the McDonnell Douglas Tulsa Management Club held this exhibition as a fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program's scholarship fund. On a sticker on the dust cover: "Z-6; fife; 'Trader on Rock.'" On the dust cover: "Z-6; Fife; 'Trader on Rock,' Z-7."
