title: Buffalo and deer dance
creator: Da, Popovi
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of 12 dancing figures. There are four deer dancers, two antelope dancers, three mountain sheep dancers, two buffalo dancers and one female dancer. The female dancer is wearing traditional ceremonial dance for a woman performing the Buffalo Dance. Her clothing consists of a handwoven one-shoulder dress with an embroidered hem, which is tied with a multicolored handwoven sash.
condition: slight foxing, small stains, small gouge  near bottom left of center; museum mounted
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, June, 1996. Stamped on the back: "The Studio, U.S. Indian School, Santa Fe, New Mexico." Sticker on the back of the painting: "Collection of Dorothy Dunn." Written on the back of the painting: "Tony Martinez (Popovi Da); San Ildefonso Pueblo; 'Buffalo and Deer Dance'; 1937."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Mow-Way 1871 Comanche
creator: Watkins, James
description: A portrait of the head and shoulders of a Native American man. He is facing the viewer with his head turned slightly to the left. He is wearing what looks like a bear's claw in his hair on the left side. A small braid is hanging down from where the claw is attached. He is also wearing a brown vest over a gray shirt. At his throat is a large disk, perhaps a shell, on a leather thong. This drawing is done on aqua mat board.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, October 10, 1979. This drawing was one of two by Mr. Watkins purchased at the time. The other drawing was "Iron Sack, Chief of Kiowa-Apache." On a card taped to the dust cover: "'Mow-Way 1871 Comanche'" (on reverse) "The Art Market, Tulsa, OK."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Leaving for the trading post
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A reproduction of a painting of a man, a woman and a child, all facing left as they prepare to get in a canoe-type boat in a bayou. They are wearing traditional appliqued Seminole clothing and the man has a sack over his right shoulder. His left hand is resting on a walking stick. The man is in front with the child between him and the woman. The woman's hands are resting on the child's shoulders. A large orange setting sun is behind them.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow. Printed signature: Fred Beaver, 77. Glued to the dust cover: "Fred Beaver; Fred Beaver, Creek, paints to 'help bridge the gap.' 'My paintings show the non-Indians what the original Indians looked like, how they lived and worked, and so there is more knowledge and understanding.' Beaver, a noted vocalist, is a self-taught artist who paints while listening to music. His paintings have won over 200 top awards, including the grand prize at Philbrook in Tulsa in 1958. He was first winner of the Waite Phillips Indian Artist Award in 1963."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: After the Gold Rush (reproduction)
creator: Love, Ralph
description: A reproduction a painting of an old framed building that is partially collapsed. It appears to be located on a hillside in a mountain valley. On the left is the corner of another building. Portions of two fences connect the two buildings.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Gifted to Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow by Ralph Love. The Zarrows own the original oil painting (see jmz.113). On the bottom of the reproduction in pencil: "To Maxine and Jack Zarrow who own my original painting, 'After the Gold Rush.'" The Certificate of Authenticity is glued to the dust cover: "Title 'After the Gold Rush'; Artist: Ralph Love; Total Edition Size: 962; Printed at Lake Shore Litho, Chicago in 1978/79."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Zuni Comanche dancer
creator: Herrera, Joe
subject: Cochiti
description: A painting of a single figure facing right. The figure is wearing braids and a headband decorated with feathers. The figure is also wearing a white buckskin shirt that has long wide fringe hanging from it, a fringed kilt with a fox skin hanging down the back, leather leggings and dance moccasins. The figure holds a stick with a drum attached to it in the left hand and a drumstick in the right hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, June 2, 1995. On the dust cover: "Joe Herrera original watercolor, circa 1950, 'Zuni Comanche Dancer'; purchased from Howard Huston, Hurst TX, June 2, 1995."

title: 200 years with old glory
creator: Juharos, Stephen
description: A reproduction of a painting depicting the birth and growth of our nation. An image of George Washington is at the center of this circular painting and around him there are scenes from U.S. history. These scenes include pilgrims arriving in the U.S., pioneers, the Civil War, WWI and WWII, men landing on the moon, farmers and the liberty bell.
condition: fading; frame separating at the corners; acidic mats; cardboard backing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack Zarrow via special order from Stephen Juharos, Sedona, AZ, May 18, 1976. Data provided by Commemorative Imports, Bayport, MN: Mr. Zarrow visited the artist's studio and was very impressed with this print. He asked for print number 1776 but was told it had not been printed yet. The artist said he would send it to him when it was available. Postcard taped to the dust cover: "May 17, 1976 'Dear Sir: Today the Print #1776 has been sent to your address. Thank you Prof. Juharos.'" Also taped to the dust cover is an advertisement for print with information about the artist and the print.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ascending dream
creator: Shoemaker, Ben Adair
subject: Quapaw (culture or style); Shawnee (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a brown peyote bird with its wings against sides and its beak pointing upward. On the body of the bird, within a teardrop-shaped dark blue area, there is a depiction of a seated figure dressed in red. The figure's arms are crossed and it appears to be meditating. Above the figure's head, there is a crescent moon and stars.

creator: Roybal, Jose D.
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a dancing man wearing a Mudhead Kachina mask. The figure is facing left. He has a brown scarf, perhaps animal skin, around his neck and is wearing a black breechclout. In his right hand, he is holding a rattle and in his left hand, he is holding an evergreen branch. The toes of his right foot are touching the ground and his left leg is bent at the knee.

title: Gaff - Staff
creator: Petersen, Eric
description: An etching of a female scarecrow with a large sunflower for a face. She is wearing a blue blouse that has gray sleeves. Over the blouse she is wearing a multi-patterned sleeveless dress that has two gingerbread-like figures in the middle of the skirt. She is also wearing red-and-black checkered stockings. In her right hand, she is holding a basket full of eggs and a white bird is sitting on her right shoulder. In her left hand, she is holding a fish and there is a shepherd's crook attached to her left arm. Two corn plants are behind her, one on either side. On the ground to the left there is a beehive and a small dog. On the ground to the right, there is a cat. In the background, there are two hills with a ram on the one to the right and a ewe on the one to the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a NARSAD Artwork Exhibit, which was held at the Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, OK, November 17, 1999. The exhibition was to benefit the Mental Health Association in Tulsa, OK. In addition to this painting, the Zarrows purchased two others: "Forest Glen," which they donated to the Mental Health Association, and "Face to Face" by Susan Foldy, which they gifted.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Seven Yeibichai dancers)
creator: Tsihnahjinnie, Andy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of seven Yeibichai dancers. They are all dressed the same in high-top dance boots, a gray kilt, a silver-and-turquoise concha belt, silver-and-turquoise wrist guards and a round-topped headdress with a green ruff around the neck. The four in the background are facing left and the three in the foreground are facing right. The headdresses are all the same with the exception of the one in the center front: his headdress has 12 feathers on it while the others only have two.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, October 20, 1999.

title: Up
creator: Duecker, Otto
signature: O Duecker 8/99 (script, On the back of the painting)
description: A painting of the side of a cardboard box with a square opening cut in it, creating two horizontal flaps. The upper flap is slightly open and the bottom one is forming a shelf. On this shelf, there are three strawberries and two drops of water. To the left of the shelf, the letter U is printed on the box. On the right side of the shelf, an arrow pointing upward is printed on the box. Below the shelf, on the right side, there is a tear in the surface of the box and a water drop.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a wall sale at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, December 15, 1999. This painting was one of three works purchased by the Zarrows at this exhibition. The other two were: a painting, "The Yellow Dress," by M.C. Poulson (jmz.399) and a sculpture, "Feeding Frenzy," by Daniel Kronberg (jmz.S27).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Yellow dress
creator: Poulsen, M. C.
description: A three-quarter-length portrait of a young Native American girl who is facing left with her head turned toward the viewer. She has long black braids that are wrapped in fur. In her hair, she is wearing a shell disk with two green feathers attached. She is also wearing a yellow cloth dress with red stripes on the bell-shaped sleeves. In addition, she has a red scarf tied around her neck and is holding a feather fan in her hands.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, December 15, 1999. This is one of three works purchased by the Zarrows at this exhibition. The other two were: a painting, "Up," by Otto Duecker (jmz.398), and a sculpture, "Feeding Frenzy," by Daniel Kronberg (jmz.S27). On the back of the painting: "9 X 12, oil panel, Oct 27, 1999, 'The Yellow Dress,' Crow Indian girl 5 years old at Cody Pow Wow, 1999" and the artist's signature.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Round dance with funeral home fan
creator: Jones, Ruthe Blalock
subject: Delaware; Shawnee (culture or style); Peoria
signature: 1994 ChuLun-Dit Ruthe Blalock Jones (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of five women dancers facing the viewer. Three of the women are wearing fringed buckskin dresses. The fourth is wearing a fringed shawl, and the fifth is wearing a red fabric dress. Three of the women are holding beaded feather fans, and the woman second from the right is holding a funeral home fan.

title: Benton
creator: Cochran, George M.
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
signature: Cochran inside an arrow outline (printed, lower right)
description: A charcoal portrait of Thomas Hart Benton. He is facing the viewer and has his chin resting on the back of his right hand.
condition: scratches around the face; gluing on the back; tearing on the right side; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at an antique store in downtown Tahlequah, OK, circa 1996. The proprietor believed it to be a self-portrait by Thomas Hart Benton, in part because the drawing came from Kansas City. The Zarrows did not think it was by Benton and wanted to have it authenticated. They offered the woman half of what she was asking for the drawing and agreed to pay the balance if it was by Benton. The staff at The Gilcrease Museum examined it and determined it was a drawing of Benton done by Cherokee artist, George M. Cochran.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pow-wow dancer)
creator: Palmer, Dixon
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow dancer whose body is painted black. His body is facing right and his head is turned to the left. He is wearing a roach headdress with three feathers attached, a shoulder collar, bow guards on his wrists, a feather bustle with trailers, a red breechclout, bands of bells just below his knees and dance moccasins. In his left hand, he is holding a feather fan and in his right hand, he is holding a flute.
condition: brittle paper; stained; acidic mats; cardboard backing; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Three blanket-wrapped Native American men)
creator: Palmer, Dixon
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A painting of three blanket-wrapped Native American men. Their heads are turned to the left, though each man's body is facing a different direction. The man on the left is turned partially to the right. He is wearing a black and red blanket and has five feathers in his hair. The man in the center has his back turned to the viewer and is wearing a blue blanket with designs in red. He has two feathers in his hair and a bow and quiver hanging across his back. The man on the right is facing left and is wearing a green blanket with a wide band of pink at the bottom edge. He is also wearing a roach headdress with two feathers attached to it and a shield hanging across his back.
condition: water staining down the right side; brittle paper; pin holes around the edges; tearing along center left edge; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Buffalo dancer
creator: Yazz, Beatien
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man from the waist up. He is facing right and is wearing a buffalo headdress. He is wearing a bone hair pipe and bead choker around his neck, blue bands on his forearms and a bow guard on his left wrist. In his left hand, he is holding a bow and in his right hand, he is holding a rattle. Behind the rattle, there is a moon. The background is black.

title: Untitled (Black lizard)
creator: Lovato, Charles
subject: Santo Domingo
description: A sand painting of a stylized black lizard. His head is facing the upper left corner as his body and tail form an elongated Z. His tail is pointing to the lower right corner. His tongue appears to be an arrow. There is a black line extending diagonally from the right side of the painting, going behind the lizard, and stopping at a point just below the lizard's left foot where it makes a right angle turn and extends to the bottom of the painting.

title: Zuni Fire God
creator: Shebola, Sullivan
subject: Zuni
description: A painting of a man facing left who is dressed as a Zuni god. His body is painted gray with multicolored spots. He is wearing a mask over his head that is painted the same way. The mask has feathers attached to the top with a white rope. An antelope carcass hangs across the front of his body and under his left arm. He is wearing a brown-and-turquoise kilt, a green sash and dance boots. In his right hand, he is holding a burning bundle and in his left hand, he is holding a bundle of yucca leaves. The title of the painting is painted in the bottom left.
condition: soiling along the right side; restoration and cleaning, The Art Market, Tulsa, OK

title: Untitled (Still life of baskets and pottery)
creator: Nez, Guy, Jr.
subject: Navajo (culture or style)

title: Kiowa fancy war dancer
creator: Williams, David Emmett (Tos-que)
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Tonkawa (culture or style); Apache (culture or style)
description: A drawing of a fancy war dancer facing slightly to the left. He is in motion with his right foot off the floor and his left knee bent. He is holding a stick with thongs attached to it in each hand and his right hand is raised at head height while his left arm is lowered, at about hip height. He is dressed in the clothing of a powwow fancy war dancer, including a feather bustle and a headdress.

description: A landscape painting of a winding highway that starts in the right foreground and winds through a valley. A body of water can be seen through the trees in the center of the painting. There are mountains in the far background.

provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at a wall sale at the Gilcrease Museum's annual American Art in Miniature exhibition, Tulsa, OK, November 6, 1998. This painting was one of two purchased. The other painting was "Breaktime" by Steve Forbis (jmz.416).

title: Mississippi Valley mansion
creator: Dobbs, Lorraine
description: A drawing of the entryway of a home. The door in the center is standing open and a fountain can be seen in the forecourt. A gold chandelier with four large white globes is hanging from the ceiling. There are stairs on the right and windows on each side of the front door. There is a doorway and closed door in the left wall. On the side of the closed door closest to the window, there is a small table. On the other side of the closed door there is a small couch. The floor appears to be wood and there is a Persian carpet in the center of it.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow. On a sticker on the dust cover: "'Morning at Mono Lake - A California Journey,' Pastel, Carole Klein." Framing by Boston Avenue Frame Shop, Tulsa, OK.

title: Trumpet lilies
creator: Dobbs, Lorraine
description: A drawing of four lily plants growing in front of three rocks. There are three buds and eight white blossoms that have gold throats and red veins. The blossoms fill the upper two-thirds of the drawing.

title: Breaktime
creator: Forbis, Steve
description: A three-quarter length portrait of a young Native American boy who is holding a red soda can in his right hand. He is facing right. He has a rolled-up, flowered, red scarf tied around his head and he is wearing a red velvet shirt. He has a turquoise-and-silver broach pinned on his front just under his collar and he is also wearing a turquoise nugget necklace.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Buckskin colt
creator: Lee, Charles
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a young horse facing right. He has a gold-colored body while his tail and mane are black. In addition, there are black markings on his lower legs. His head is raised, his ears are perked up and his legs are braced as though ready for action.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 3, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. The others were by Robert Chee, Tony Begay, Geraldine Gutierrez, Ignatius Palmer, Nick Poleahla, Percy Sandy, Robert Redbird, Dave Yazzie, Raphael Medina, Robert Draper, Fred Cleveland, Jim Abeita, Neil David, and Douglas Yazzie. Auction lot #194. On the back of the painting: "...By Charles Lee, Navajo Artist 'Buckskin Colt'...."

title: Flute dancer
creator: Blackowl, Archie
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow dancer playing a flute as he dances. His left knee is raised as his legs move toward the left, his torso is facing the viewer, and his head is turned to the right. He is wearing a roach headdress, a matching beaded necklace, upper-arm bands, wrist guards with fringe and a belt. He is also wearing upper- and lower-back bustles, a long red breechclout, a band of large bells around each calf just below the knee and beaded dance moccasins. He is holding the flute up to his mouth with his left hand and he is holding a feather fan in his right hand.
condition: paper surface loss at the top left; discoloration; painting has slipped down; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Henry Belink of Belink's Studio, Santa Fe, NM, at their home in Tulsa, OK, June 22, 1981. On a piece of old dust cover attached to the back: "Archie Blackowl - Kiowa, tempera/watercolor paper." On tape at the top of the dust cover: "Painted in the late 50's." A note from Henry Belink: "Archie Blackowl's 'Flute Player' is estimated to be painted in 1950s, the late 1950s. Blackowl was a good friend of the David Holway's. 13 5/8 X 9 5/8 Tulsa, Oklahoma."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Comanche hunter)
creator: Poleahla, Nick
subject: Hopi-Tewa (culture or style)
description: A drawing of a dancer in a traditional Comanche hunter's costume. The dancer is facing left. He is wearing a painted face mask with feather decorations on the sides and a band of braided ribbons across the forehead. In addition, he is wearing a beaded shoulder collar, beaded upper-arm bands, beaded bow guards on his wrist, a deer-hide kilt and high-topped, hard-soled dance boots. He is wearing a black, red and green handwoven belt across his chest and around his waist. An animal pelt is hanging down the back of his kilt. He is in a squatting position with his right hand raised and holding an arrow while his left hand is waist height and is holding a bow.
condition: creasing and smudging along the upper right side

title: Prairie bandit
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a grass-covered prairie with a fence down the center that stretches from the center background to past the right side of the painting. The carcass of a dead coyote is hanging by its rear legs from the nearest fence post on the right. A rabbit is sitting up on its hind legs to the left of the coyote. Storm clouds are billowing in the distance on the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Brummett Echohawk, Tulsa, OK, July 8, 1980. This painting was one of twenty purchased from Brummett at the time. On the receipt: "'Prairie Bandit,' tempera, Art size 6" X 10", Date painted: 1978, 'This coyote was seen hanging from a fence post on a bald prairie east of Red Rock, Oklahoma.'" On the backing: "'Prairie Bandit,' Echohawk, artist...."

title: Untitled (Two dancers in eagle costumes)
creator: Pena, Maria Antonia
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two dancers dressed in Pueblo eagle costumes as four men beat four large drums. All the figures are facing left. The dancers are in the lower left and the drummers are in a group in the upper right. The nearest drummer is wearing a red shirt and has a feather in his hair, the drummer behind him is wearing a yellow shirt and has a red headband, the drummer behind him is wearing a blue shirt and a war bonnet, and the drummer behind him is wearing a black shirt and the upper half of his face is painted red.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Hillside house
creator: Jarboe, Virginia Helen Rodecker
description: A painting of a house that is sitting on a hill as seen from below and to the left. The house is partially obscured by plants on the left. It is two stories and is painted yellow with white trim, has a porch on the right side, and appears to be decorated in a Victorian style. On the first level, there is a bay window made up of four casement windows and above it, on the second level, there is a single casement window.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist at an exhibition of her work, Tulsa, OK, 1979.  The exhibition was sponsored by Dick Barber at the Utica State Bank. Mr. Barber was a trustee of the bank and, for several years, sponsored two yearly art exhibits. Any money raised went to various charities.

title: Oklahoma fancy dancer
creator: Wilson, Charles Banks
description: A lithograph of a powwow fancy dancer in motion and facing the viewer. He is wearing a roach headdress and upper- and lower-back feather bustles. In addition, he is wearing beaded accessories that consist of a headband, forearm bands, a breast plate, a belt, wrist guards and dance moccasins. There are bands of large bells around his upper calves just under his knees. His knees are bent and his right foot is raised as he dances. In his left hand he is holding a small flute. Around him, there are numerous sketches of other dancers.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Yeibichai dancer)
creator: Begay, Harrison
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man facing the viewer and wearing a Yeibichai mask with thirteen feathers framing it. The mask has a collar of evergreen boughs. The dancer is in a semi-squatting position with both knees bent. He is wearing a tanned deerskin draped over his left shoulder and tied at his waist on his right side. He is also wearing an orange shirt, brown pants with silver buttons down the side seams and high-topped, hard-soled dance boots. The tops of the boots are tied up with narrow, red, hand-woven ties. He is holding evergreen sprigs in his right hand and a leather bag in his left hand.
condition: some discoloration; acidic mats; museum mounting

title: Straight dancer
creator: Wagoshe, Russell William
subject: Osage (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man with long wrapped black braids who is participating in a Straight Dance. He is facing right and wearing a roach headdress with one upright feather and two smaller feathers hanging down in front of his face. He is also wearing a purple shirt, a light red scarf around his neck held with a shell slider, a beaded belt, black pants, a black breechclout, two bands of bells around his upper calves and beaded dance moccasins. A long trailer with feathers and ornaments attached is hanging down his back from his collar to the ground.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Long Hair Hopi Kachina
creator: Polelonema, Otis
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of two identical dancers dressed as  Hopi Long Hair Kachina facing the viewer. They are wearing a longhair mask, handwoven and embroidered kilts tied with a handwoven black, green and red sash, and dance boots. They are also wearing two large bells tied to their calves just below their left knees and yellow body paint. A fox skin is hanging down the back of their kilts and can be seen behind their legs. They are each wearing a bow guard on their left wrist and holding an evergreen bough in their left hand and a gourd rattle in their right hand. "Hopi Kachinas" is written at the bottom of the painting.
condition: slight creasing; water staining by the feather of the left figure; staining between the figures' knees; soiling down the right side; conservation mounting; conservation glass

creator: Vigil, Tim
subject: Tesuque
signature: Tim Vigil 1971 on a feather painting (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a woman grinding corn using a mano and metate, both made of stone. She is facing right. In the background, there are corn plants. In the foreground, there are three ears of corn, a coiled basket and a black ceramic jar full of ground corn.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow in Tulsa from Henry B. Belink of Santa Fe, NM, June 22, 1981. At the top of the dust cover: "Purchased from artist by Henry B. Belink family 1971." On a piece of old backing, glued to the dust cover, in the artist's handwriting: "Artist Tim Vigil; Tribe Tesuque Santa Fe, New Mexico; Medium watercolor; Title 'Corn Grinder'; 1924-1972."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Tewa clowns with YA-NI-WAH dancers
creator: David, Neil
subject: Hopi-Tewa (culture or style)
signature: N David '72 Tewa Hopi (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of four dancers and a drummer. There is a pottery-like border design across the bottom and up the sides of the painting. From left to right, the first and fourth dancers are Koshare Clowns. The first one is facing slightly to the left and the fourth one is facing the viewer. They are wearing the traditional clothing of a Koshare clown, which includes black-and-white striped body paint, and they are dancing and singing. The dancer second from the left is male and is facing left. He is holding an arrow in his left hand and a rattle in his right hand. The dancer third from the left is facing left and is female. She is holding a basket tray in her right hand and two feathers in her left hand. The figure on the far right is a drummer and he is facing the viewer. He is beating a drum that is suspended by means of leather straps around his neck.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. Originally framed by Village frame, Santa Barbara, CA.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Going south
creator: Chee, Robert
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a young Navajo boy sitting on a horse while the horse drinks from a small puddle of water. Both horse and rider are facing left. The boy is leaning back on his left arm and watching two birds in the sky. The horse is brown with a white mane and tail, and a long white blaze on his face that includes his nose and mouth. The horse also has four white socks. The bridle is simple and is made of rope while a blanket serves as the saddle.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 4, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. Auction lot #688. On the dust cover: "Going South." In the auction catalog: "Portraying a Navajo boy watering his horse, titled 'Going south,' painted by deceased artist Robert Chee, circa 1960s."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pueblo maiden in traditional costume)
creator: Gutierrez, Geraldine
subject: Santa Clara; San Ildefonso
description: A painting of a Pueblo maiden dressed in a traditional ceremonial costume. She is facing the viewer. He clothing consists of a feathered headdress containing nineteen feathers in a fan-like arrangement, a black handwoven and embroidered one-shoulder dress, a rain sash and white dance boots. She is holding feather fans in both hands, which are raised and held out away from her sides. On either side of the headdress there are two stylized butterflies. On the left of the figure, there is a stylized corn plant and below the figure, there is a geometric design.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. Auction lot #901.

title: Apache dancer
creator: Cleveland, Fred
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of an Apache Mountain Spirit dancer in motion painted against a black background. The dancer's feet are striding toward the right while his upper body is turned to face the viewer. He is wearing a headdress and a mask. A red band with three feathers attached is tied across the lower half of the mask. Four white triangles with circles on the point are painted on his chest and he is wearing a two-layered deerskin kilt held up by a concha belt. On his feet, he is wearing Apache boots with circular tabs on the toes. He is holding a sword-like white stick in each hand and there are long red ribbons swirling downward tied to his forearms. The figure is backlighted by what appears to be a fire.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. Auction lot #937. From the auction catalog: "Navajo Acrylic Painting, Titled 'Apache Fire Dancer,' a night scene lighted by fire, painted by Fred Cleveland, Navajo Artist." On a sticker: "Enchanted Mesa, Fred and Margaret Chase...Albuquerque, New Mexico."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ceremonial drummer
creator: Mopope, Stephen
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man from the waist up. He is wearing a war bonnet and facing left. He has long black braids and is wearing a shell disk and pipe bead necklace around his neck. A black-and-red blanket is partially wrapped around him. He is holding a flat drum in front of him with his right hand while he beats it with the drumstick he is holding in his left hand. He appears to be singing.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Monument and Yeibeichai with tree and plants
creator: Paladin, David Chethlahe
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Circle pierced with a line that comes out of a semicircle (drawn, lower right)
description: An abstract painting of a monolith, or monument, with a sand painting of a Yeibichai-like figure that seems to be coming out of the ground behind and to the right of the monolith. There is a swirling, cloud-like design between the monolith and the figure. Below the figure, on the right, there is a twisted tree and in the foreground, there is a yucca-like plant and a bush.

creator: Taylor, Dwane
description: A painting of a lone tipi on the plains with mountains in the distance. There are traces of snow on the ground and the stormy sky is colored gold as the sun sets. title: Rounding up the wild horses
creator: Lee, Charles
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Navajo man herding five horses at a gallop across the reservation. The man is wearing a red headband, no shirt, dark blue pants and high-topped, hard-soled moccasins with silver buttons up the sides. He is using a deer hide for a saddle and a single rope tied around the horse's lower jaw as a bridle. The horse he is riding is a paint and the horses he is chasing are black, white, a bay, a buckskin and  sorrel. The man is waving a deer skin in his right hand. There are mesas in the background and the sky is overcast.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via absentee bid from a Skinner, Inc. auction, Bolton, MA, January 23, 1995. On the back of the frame: "Skinner 16241 Lot 347." A photo of the artist and his wife holding the painting is included in the artist's file.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Traditional women
creator: Houseman-Whitehawk, Laurie
subject: Ho-Chunk; Santee
signature: Laurie H. White Hawk '99 (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of two Lakota women in traditional dress as they participate in a powwow dance. They are facing the left, one in the foreground and one in the background. The woman on the left is wearing a headband and a feather in her hair. She is dressed in a buckskin dress with long fringe that is decorated with orange, white, red and yellow beading. She is carrying a shawl in the same colors folded over her arms and a feather fan in her hand. The woman on the right is wearing the same clothing but the beading on her dress is dark blue, light blue and red, and her shawl is the same colors. She has a feather in her hair, but no headband. Both women are wearing leggings and beaded moccasins in colors that match their clothing.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, March 19, 1999. At the time the Zarrows purchased this painting, Ms. White Hawk was working at the Art Market, although her home was in Lawrence, Kansas. The Zarrows enjoyed meeting and visiting with her.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

One bird is facing left, one is facing the viewer and the other two, the two on the right, are facing right. The bird on the far right appears to be eating red berries. There are some red flowers in the lower left corner of the painting.

title: Apaches on horseback
creator: Naha, Raymond
subject: Hopi-Tewa (culture or style)
description: A painting of three riders on horses coming up a trail in the Arizona foothills. They are riding to the right and all three are carrying rifles in their right hands. All three have long black hair and are wearing headbands. The first rider, who is in the center of the painting, is riding a bay horse with a white blaze and wearing a white shirt and a brown vest. The second rider, who is behind the first, is riding a black horse and wearing a fringed buckskin shirt and pants. The third rider is riding a gray horse and wearing a brown vest with no shirt. The closest mountains are covered with Saguaro cactuses and desert plants.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Green teacup
creator: Lebow, David
description: A still life painting of two vases full of a variety of flowers, a bowl of fruit and a variety of other objects. From left to right there is a stemmed blue-green glass, a cream-colored cream pitcher, a grouping of an apple, an orange and a lemon, the two vases, one gold and one red, a green china teacup, and a light blue china bowl with five pieces of fruit in it. In the left foreground there is a single orange slice.

description: A lithograph of the Western Wall with a menorah superimposed on it. Above the menorah, there is the face of a man whose head is covered as he looks upward.
condition: undamaged; museum mounting; frame broken at top

title: Joseph and his brethren
creator: Leiber, Gerson
description: An etching of a figure upside down in a black hole. The only parts of him that extend above the hole are his tied hands, his feet and the hem of his multicolored garment. Below this figure, along the bottom edge of the etching, there are nine men standing on both sides of the bottom of the hole, two to the left and seven to the right. At the top of the etching, above the hole, there are four men dressed in black who seem to be observing what is going on below. One of the men holds a torah.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Philbrook Museum's Collectors Choice 14 art show and sale, Tulsa, OK, 1974. These shows were held for several years by the museum. The director, Donald G. Humphrey, would go to New York City and visit various galleries, seeking artworks they were willing to loan on commission for the show. He would then bring back a selection of artworks to be sold at the Collectors Choice show. On a sticker on the back of the frame: "Associated American Artists.... An original work of art, Artist Leiber, Title 'Joseph and His Brethren,' medium etching...."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Calico ghost town hotel
creator: Sanchez, Lawrence
description: A painting of the front of a clapboard building that has a porch roof over a wood walkway. A recessed door is in the center of the painting with the sign "Country Kitchen Gifts N' Fixins" hanging over it. Various objects are visible through large windows on either side of the door. A faded sign that says "Rooms" is above the door and porch roof.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Wagner Gallery, Austin, TX, March 26, 1980. On the back of the painting: "'Calico Ghost town Hotel' (near Barstow, California, silver mining area) by Lawrence Sanchez, 1979."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Navajo reservation scene with hogan)
creator: Draper, Robert
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a hogan with a covered wagon behind it. There is a summer brush shelter in front of it. In the right background, there is a monolith and in the distance, there are mesas. The sky is stormy and thunderclouds are building. Rain can be seen falling between the monolith and the hogan.

title: Untitled (Navajo woman in orange shawl)
creator: Franklin, John
description: An impressionistic portrait of a Navajo woman who appears to be seated in a garden. She is wearing her hair in the traditional wrapped style at the back of her head. She is wrapped in an orange shawl and is facing left. There are flowers and leaves in the background.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Maxine Zarrow at an antique show in Tulsa, OK, from an antique dealer from Kansas City, MO, circa 1995. The dealer told Mrs. Zarrow he had hung the painting in his home for some time. There were few paintings at this antique show, and Mrs. Zarrow recognized this one as having been painted by an artist whose works were already in her collection.

title: Scaffold burial
creator: Blackowl, Archie
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Plains Native American scaffold burial. The scaffold is in the center of the painting and is on a raised area. Hanging from the scaffold are a feathered war bonnet, a shield and a pipe bag. At the base of the raised area are three figures. In the center is a woman wrapped in a blanket and standing with her back to the viewer. On the left is a boy, and on the right is a girl. Both are kneeling and facing the woman.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the D. F. Henry Company, Tulsa, OK, December 14, 1980.

title: Snow hunt
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man with a bow about to shoot a buck that is standing in a meadow in the middle of a snowstorm. The hunter, dressed in buckskin, is crouching behind a tree on the left as he nocks an arrow. In the center of the painting, a buck with a four-by-four rack is looking toward the viewer while a doe standing beside him looks for food in the snow.  In the sky above and to the right of the hunter, there is a spirit figure that is pointing toward the deer. On the right, four ducks are taking flight.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Troy Anderson One-Man Show, Muskogee, OK, April 13, 1980. The Zarrows purchased 19 paintings by Mr. Anderson at this time. On the dust cover: "1980, 'Snow Hunt,' Acrylic."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Navajo reservation scene with riders)
creator: Draper, Robert
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a group of riders circling around a sweat lodge and shade arbor. The riders are cantering and the dust is flying. In the distance, additional riders and wagons can be seen approaching. To the left, there is a summer brush hogan with three women standing outside and a wagon with two children in it is behind the hogan. In the distance, there are mesas with clouds filling the sky above them.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Northern California coast
creator: Gonske, Walt
signature: Northern California Coast '72 Walt Gonske (printed, lower right)
description: A landscape painting of a rocky seacoast with large rock outcroppings extending out from the shore. The day is calm and the sea laps gently against the rocks. Very little sand is visible.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Sam S. and Patsy Smith, Houston, TX, May 1981. This painting is one of three by Gonske purchased from the Smiths. The other two paintings were "The Houndstooth Taos" (jmz.155) and "Taos Man" (jmz.130). The Smiths had purchased the paintings directly from Gonske, circa 1978. This painting was exhibited at the Thomas Gilcrease Museum of American History and Art, Tulsa, Oklahoma, 'Tulsans Collect,' February 16 - April 15, 1990. (B.90.88.C)."

title: Lady on horse
creator: Buffalo, Benjamin, Sr.
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of a young Native American woman riding a white-and-black Appaloosa. The top of her dress is covered with sewn-on shells or elk teeth and she is wearing beaded boots. An orange shawl is hanging over the back of the saddle just behind the cantle and a bag beaded with the image of a horse is hanging off of the saddle horn. The horse is wearing a breast band beaded with geometric designs.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Doris Littrell at the Oklahoma Indian Art Gallery, Oklahoma City, OK, May 24, 1991. This painting was one of two purchased at the time. The other painting was "Mountain Sheep Dancer" by Pablita Velarde. Excerpt from a letter from Doris Littrell: "From Dr. Bernard's collection - lives in Oregon and are retiring and moving to smaller home. They bought from Tribal Arts (Beverly Baum) in 1976."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Creek two step dance
creator: Harjo, Albert
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man and woman dancing side by side with the man closest to viewer as they move toward the right. The man is wearing a wide-brimmed black hat with two feathers attached to the hatband, a lavender shirt with blue polka-dots, a maroon vest, a white belt with gold-and-blue stripes that has long tassels hanging down, blue pants and cowboy boots. The woman is wearing a black scarf tied around her neck, a red blouse and a long purple skirt. This painting is done on blue Crescent mat board.

title: Medicine man
creator: Joshua, Lee Roy
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
signature: Joshua (shaped in an inverted V) '79 (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a man sitting on a hollow log facing the viewer. A bucket is sitting on the ground in front of him between his feet and he is holding a long reed or stick in his hands. One end of the reed is in the bucket and the other end is in front of his chest. He has long black hair with a single feather at the back of his head. He is wrapped in a red blanket and is wearing blue leggings and high-topped fringed moccasins with red scarves tied around his calves to hold them up.

title: Watching the enemy
creator: Harjo, Albert
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man wearing a war bonnet and sitting on a brown-and-white paint horse. Both horse and rider are facing right. title: Plot

title: Pawnee peace prayer
creator: Echohawk, Brummett
subject: Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A drawing of a man on a horse that is standing on a snowy hillside. The man is holding up a peace pipe toward the sky with the mouthpiece pointed upward. title: Visit with the arrow maker
creator: Marler, Nadine
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
signature: Nadine Marler and her name in Cherokee (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a man sitting on a stump as he breaks a flake out of a piece of flint. He is facing right. Two young boys and a toddler are watching him. Four arrow points are lying on the ground in front of the man's right foot.

title: Free entrance
creator: Jones, Susan T.
description: A painting of three boys trying to sneak into a circus by going under a circus tent. A policeman has caught them in the act. The boys are crouched and facing toward the right as they lift the edge of the tent. Two of the boys are looking at the policeman. The man has his back to the viewer and is on the right side of the painting. He is standing with his hands on his hips and only the right half of him, from waist to torso, is visible.

title: Warrior of the Plains
creator: Harjo, Albert
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Plains Native American warrior riding a horse in a snowstorm. The horse and rider are moving toward the left. The warrior is wearing a wolf headdress, a buckskin suit and moccasins. He is carrying a shield and a spear in his left hand. The spear is carried horizontally, tip forward. The horse is a gray-and-white paint with red circles painted around his eyes and red bars painted across his nose.

title: Remembering the past
creator: Joshua, Lee Roy
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
signature: Joshua (shaped in an inverted V) '79 (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a white-haired man who is facing the viewer. He is standing hunched over with his knees bent. He is holding a walking stick in his right hand and he is holding a lavender-colored blanket around his shoulders with his left hand. He is looking at a buffalo skull that is sitting in the grass in front of him and the image of a white buffalo head is floating in the air behind his head. "Remembering the Past" is printed at the bottom of the painting.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Seminole
creator: Joshua, Lee Roy
subject: Creek (culture or style); Seminole
signature: Joshua (shaped in an inverted V) '79 (printed, lower right)
description: A portrait of the head of a Native American man who is wearing a purple turban with a long white feather attached at the top and hanging down his back. There is also a black feather attached at the top of his turban, and it is hanging over his face. A pink scarf is tied around his neck. The man is facing left. "Seminole" is printed at the bottom of the painting.

title: Paying respect
creator: Harjo, Albert
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a scaffold burial on a hill with four buffalo standing around it. A spear decorated with a beaded bag and two feathers is leaning against the scaffold on the right. A buffalo skull and a shield are hanging from two of the other supports. There is a gold moon in the sky in the upper left. A falling star is streaking across the sky behind the platform. This painting was done on red Crescent mat board.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Kingfisher
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of the face of a Native American woman with a tan scarf tied over her head. She is facing left. Below her face, there is a kingfisher sitting on a tree branch. The bird is facing right. At the bottom of the painting, there is a scene from the Trail of Tears depicting ten figures moving in single file away from the viewer in a snowstorm. The figures are wrapped in blankets and their backs are toward the viewer.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Time of plenty
creator: Bales, Jean
subject: Iowa
description: A painting of 45 women and girls dressed in calico tear dresses as they pick and shuck corn and visit. Nine are seated, three are on horses, one is riding in a travois, and the rest are standing. There are eight white dogs, two horses and a foal included in the painting.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist at the Tulsa Indian Art Festival, Tulsa, OK, February 23, 1996. Written by the artist on the dust cover: "'Time Of Plenty' by J Bales '95; to Jack and Maxine Zarrow Thank so much you made my show, Jeanie, Feb. 23, 1996."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Watchman
creator: Anderson, Troy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man holding a rifle that has a feather tied to the end of the barrel. He is sitting on a brown horse, and he and the horse are facing away from the viewer and slightly to the right. The man is wearing a turban and a buckskin suit and has a blue blanket wrapped around him. The man and horse are painted in front of three blue circles and there are two overlapping blue circles beneath them.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Navajo girl going to Grandma's hogan
creator: Begay, Harrison
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Harrison Begay Haskay Yahne Yah (printed, lower left)
description: A painting of a young Navajo girl facing right and wearing a traditional pulled-back and wrapped hairstyle. She is wearing a red velvet blouse with silver button decorations, a long purple gathered skirt, a handwoven green-and-white sash, hard-soled high-topped moccasins, and silver and turquoise jewelry. A brown-and-white dog is running in front of her and a lamb is gamboling along behind her. She is carrying a bunch of grass in each hands as she strides along.

title: Creek Indian mother
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a woman sitting on a tree stump under a tree and holding a child. The woman is facing left. She is dressed in a blue polka-dot blouse, a red skirt and a gray apron. Except for the woman, the child and the dog's tongue, everything in the painting is done in shades of gray. In the distance, there is a small log house on the left. In the foreground, there is a spotted gray dog with a red tongue.

title: Creek medicine man
creator: Beaver, Fred
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man sitting on a chair under a tree as he blows into a ceramic jug using a long tube. A dog is sitting on the ground in front of the man. The painting is done in shades of gray except for the man's face, his shirt, the dog's tongue and the design on a second jug. The man's is wearing a red and white polka-dot shirt and the design on the jug and the dog's tongue are red. In the background on the left, there is a small log cabin with smoke coming out of the chimney.

title: Untitled (African men fishing)
creator: Hrpe, Lohling
description: A painting of three men in two canoe-like boats fishing. In the boat closest to the viewer, a man is paddling or poling the boat toward the left. The second boat is behind the first and is also moving to the left. One of the men in the second boat is poling or paddling the boat while the second man, who is on the left, is casting a net into the water.

title: Remembering Grandmother
creator: Marler, Nadine
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
signature: Nadine Marler and Cherokee writing (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a woman wrapped in a red blanket standing outdoors in the snow with a tear on her cheek. She is facing the viewer as the wind blows her hair. Above her, there are five images of a woman. The central image is of a woman with her eyes closed, while the others show her involved in various homemaking activities that include planting corn, grinding grain, pounding corn and holding a baby.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's annual art exhibition, Muskogee, OK, October 10, 1981. On the back of the painting: "'Remembering Grandmother,' Artist - Nadine Marler."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Native American profile and buffalo head)
creator: Momaday, Al
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of the profile of a Native American man who is facing left and tilting his head back. There is a feather hanging on a lanyard from the top of his head. His face is painted with blue stripes across his forehead and from his eye down across his cheek. Above him is the head of a black buffalo that is facing the viewer. The buffalo's beard touches and blends with the man's hair. To the left of the man, there is a design of a buffalo-horned helmet shape with a gold path extending from the helmet toward the bottom of the painting. The path has buffalo hoof prints on it.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow with an absentee bid from an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 5, 1995. This painting was one of twenty purchased at this auction. Auction lot #X33.

title: Rain makers
creator: P'otsunu
subject: San Juan (Rio Grande Pueblo)
description: A stylized design that includes a row of three female figures from the waist up whose arms are connected. All three are wearing three red chokers, a shell pendant necklace and the traditional one-shoulder Pueblo dress. Their hairstyles are similar and consist of long hair on their left side and hair cut short on their right with bangs. The figure in the center has a basket balanced on her head and a rain belt at her waist. Below these figures, there is a water serpent design.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Oke Oweenge Crafts Cooperative, San Juan Pueblo, NM, March 27, 1992. This painting is one of three of Ms. Montoya's paintings purchased at the time. The other paintings were "Deer in the Fall" (jmz.499) and "Long Hair Dancer" (jmz.500). The painting was framed when purchased, but the painting was removed from the frame to protect it from acidic mats and backing. The frame was a heavy wooden frame typical of the period when the painting was done.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: image: 8 x 12 1/2 in.; matted: 14 1/4 x 18 3/4 in.

title: Deer in the fall
creator: P'otsunu
subject: San Juan (Rio Grande Pueblo)
description: A stylized pottery-type design that includes two running deer that are facing each other. There is a tree-like design between them. They are gray and black and have a red arrow running from their mouth to the middle of their torsos. They are in the upper half of the painting. Below the deer, there are two identical designs that are mirror images of each other. Below these, there is a  scalloped design. The background is  gray green and the colors used in the design are brown, orange, gray and black.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Oke Oweenge Crafts Cooperative, San Juan Pueblo, NM, March 27, 1992. This painting is one of three of Ms. Montoya's paintings purchased at the time. The other paintings were "Rain Makers" (jmz.498) and "Long Hair Dancer" (jmz.500).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Long hair dancer
creator: P'otsunu
subject: San Juan (Rio Grande Pueblo)
description: A painting of the mask or head of a Long Hair Kachina facing left. The kachina is painted in black, turquoise, gray, red, yellow and brown against a mottled tan and brown background. The face of the mask is turquoise with black lines for the eyes and the mouth. Under the face, there is a red-and-yellow band with four gray feathers hanging down. The kachina's black hair is cut in bangs across its forehead and hangs down long in back. Long black hair forms a beard underneath the red-and-yellow band. There is a red-and-yellow medallion-shaped decoration at the top of its head and wedge-shaped feathers, pointing down, are attached to the back of the head.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Oke Oweenge Crafts Cooperative, San Juan Pueblo, NM, March 27, 1992. This painting is one of three of Ms. Montoya's paintings purchased at the time. The other paintings were "Deer in the Fall" (jmz.499) and "Rain Makers" (jmz.498).
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Young man sitting
creator: Shoemaker, Ben Adair
subject: Quapaw (culture or style); Shawnee (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man sitting cross-legged on the ground. His right hand is resting on the ground and his left hand is resting on his left knee. He is facing the viewer. His hair is in braids and he is wearing two feathers on the left side of his hair. He is wearing a buckskin shirt, brown pants and moccasins. He has a necklace with a blue pendant around his neck. In the sky to his left, there is a blue circle.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Inc., Siloam Springs, AR, October 27, 1980.

title: Little people flute player
creator: Scott, Chester
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of an elf-like creature with pointed ears sitting on a white mushroom with blue spots as he plays a flute. He is facing left. He is wearing a gold-colored shirt, a long red breechclout and a feather in his hair. At the lower left of the painting is printed "Little People Flute Player".
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's annual art exhibition, Muskogee, OK, October 14, 1979. This painting won 2nd place in the Creek division of this exhibition. Taped to the back of the painting: "Artist Chester Scott, Title 'Little People Flute Player,' Medium Watercolor, ... Artist's Tribe Creek."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cheyenne wolf warrior
creator: Pahsetopah, Loren
subject: Osage (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American warrior standing on a hill with a pink circle behind him that has three concentric lighter circles around it. The warrior is facing the viewer and to the right, there is dead tree. The man is wearing a headdress made from a wolf pelt. In addition, he is wearing a red breechclout, leather leggings with decorated fringe and beaded moccasins. There is a knife in a scabbard at his waist and he is holding a rifle in a beaded case in front of him, in a horizontal position across his left forearm.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at Ruth's Turquoise, Tulsa, OK, circa November 1, 1980. On the back of the painting: "'Cheyenne Wolf Warrior,' Loren Pahsetopah Osage, 80."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cherokee medicine man
creator: Pahsetopah, Mike
subject: Osage (culture or style); Yuchi; Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a man facing the viewer and holding a bag in his right hand and a knife in his left hand. He is wearing a blue turban with blue and orange feathers curling from the tip. In addition, he is wearing a blue frock coat, buckskin leggings and plain moccasins. He is standing in the bottom right corner of the painting. In the upper left corner there are some trees silhouetted against a large orange circle, perhaps a moon.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow. On a label removed from the painting: "This painting is a Cherokee Medicine Man. The bag he is carrying contains different kinds of herbs that he has gathered from different plants. The knife he has is used for digging or cutting herbs. The clothes he is wearing was the style of the Cherokee men. Mike Pahse-topah."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

subject: Navajo (culture or style)

title: Yeibichai dancers
creator: Tsihnahjinnie, Andy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of seven Yeibichai dancers in two rows facing the viewer. Six of the dancers are dressed in almost identical traditional clothing with the only difference being the designs on their kilts. The seventh dancer, who is second from the left in the first row, is wearing a different headdress which has 11 feathers instead of two like the other dancers.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

creator: Williams, David Emmett (Tos-que)
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Tonkawa (culture or style); Apache (culture or style)
description: A painting of the head and shoulders of a Native American man with long black hair. He is facing left. He has red paint at the side of his eye and on his chin. A feather is tucked beside his left ear. There is a moon image overlapping his forehead. Ghost-like images of a line of people are on the horizon to the left of his chin.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
