title: Freeborn companions
creator: Williams, David Emmett (Tos-que)
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Tonkawa (culture or style); Apache (culture or style)
description: A painting of a young boy clinging to a bush at the edge of a precipice with his left hand, a look of alarm on his face. A rabbit is clutched in the crook of his right arm. A golden eagle with a rabbit in its claws is about to land to the left of the boy.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow. On a sticker on the front: "David Williams, 'Freeborn Companions,' original painting, no discount." On the back of the painting: "'Freeborn Companions,' an original painting by David Williams...." Taped to the painting: "'Freeborn Companions,' 9/21/80, The golden eagle depicted here was found injured when very young by the small boy. He cared for it attentively and raised it to adulthood. When grown the boy released it from captivity, but the eagle never forgot his friend. They still spent time together, as shown in this painting, as they were hunting for rabbits. Both friends were born free and lived accordingly."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Piggy back
creator: McCombs, Solomon
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A lithograph of a woman carrying a young girl on her back. The child's arms are around the woman's neck and her legs are around the woman's waist. They are moving to the right. The woman has long black hair and is wearing a brown polka-dot blouse, a blue skirt and a white apron. The girl is wearing a blue dress. Both the woman and the child are barefoot.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Deer spirit
creator: McCombs, Solomon
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: An etching of a Native American hunter kneeling by a deer carcass with his hands up raised toward a spirit image of a deer in the sky. The hunter is facing left. Between the hunter and the carcass, there is a small campfire and the spirit image is appearing in the smoke from this fire. There is a bow and arrows on the ground to the left of the hunter and an arrow in the side of the deer carcass.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Gifted to Jack and Maxine Zarrow by Margarita McCombs, the artist's wife, Tulsa, OK, January 9, 1981, in appreciation for their kindness. From Mrs. McCombs' letter: "January 9, 1981. Dear Mr. And Mrs. Zarrow, I write to you once more to thank you - this time for your kindness in sending us the delicious Christmas fruits, nuts, and chocolates. Your thoughtfulness put a special bright spot into our Christmas. My sister was hoping to get over to Gilcrease to meet you before she had to return to Washington, D.C. but there were so many details to attend to pertaining to Solomon's death that we were unable to return to the Gilcrease Museum. I am enclosing an etching of Solomon's. I hope you both like it. Again - thanks for the fruit. Sincerely, Margarita McCombs"
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: print: 10 1/4 x 7 in.

title: Ribbon dance
creator: McCombs, Solomon
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A reproduction of a painting of two women tying long ribbons in another woman's hair. The ribbons are extremely long and drag on the ground or swirl in the air. The women tying the ribbons face each other and are on either side of the other woman, who has her back to the viewer.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum Gift Shop, Tulsa, OK, March 19, 1981.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Cherokee woman warrior
creator: Hill, Joan
subject: Creek (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A round painting of a woman wearing only a breechclout and moccasins. She is riding a rearing white horse while she holds a staff, or perhaps a lance, with a flag on it. She and the horse are facing right. In the background, there is a moon, hills, a river and trees. In the foreground, to the right of the horse, there are three flags.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Indian Paintbrush Gallery, Siloam Springs, AR, December 1980. Taped to the dust cover, from the artist Joan Hill: "'Cherokee Woman Warrior' Ethnology records show several instances, in which the Indian woman joined her men, when many of the warriors had been slain in battle. They shed their own clothing, put on a loincloth and other accoutrements of the warrior and carried the lance into battle. One such incident and place is recorded in Cherokee and U.S. history as 'War Women's Creek' where several women were found among the dead warriors at battles end."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: framed: 21 x 21 in.

title: Bandits of leafy hollow
creator: Kercher, Robert A.
signature: Robert A. Kercher '80 (script, lower right margin)
description: A silkscreen of a forest floor featuring a hollow log with large leaves all around it. From left to right, the leaves gradually turn into the faces of raccoons. At the open end of the log, on the right, there are the faces of four raccoons. The artist describes this as the "permutation" of one image turning into another.

title: Camille's elusive butterflies
creator: Kercher, Robert A.
signature: Robert A. Kercher '80 (script, lower right margin)
description: A silkscreen of an autumn scene with an alert calico cat facing right with its head turned toward viewer watching butterflies. To the left of the cat there is the branch of an oak tree with the leaves falling off and blowing to the right. From left to right, the leaves gradually take the form of a butterfly. On the far right there are six butterflies. The artist describes this as the "permutation" of one image turning into another.

title: Great eggscape
creator: Kercher, Robert A.
signature: Robert A. Kercher '80 (script, lower right margin)
description: A silkscreen of a large egg with multiple, mostly uniform, cracks that are vaguely hexagonal. From right to left, they gradually take the shape of a chicken and move off of the egg into a flock of chickens. There are 21 fully formed chickens at the bottom of the print. The artist describes this as the "permutation" of one image into another.

title: Chips off the ol' block
creator: Kercher, Robert A.
signature: Robert A. Kercher (script, lower right margin)
description: A silkscreen of a close-up of a forest scene. In the upper right hand corner, there is a lower portion of a pine tree with large pinecones hanging down. From the base of the tree to the lower left, the pinecones gradually take the shape of a chipmunk. On the left there are six complete chipmunks. The artist describes this as the "permutation" of one image into another.

title: Humming bird dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Woody Crumbo (script, lower right); Crumbo (printed, lower right)
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Native American ceremonial war dancer in full regalia. He appears to move to the right as his knees and feet are facing that direction, while his upper torso is facing the viewer and his head is turned to the left. As he dances his knees are bent, and his right leg is raised while his left foot is on the floor. He is wearing a feathered roach headdress and large feathered arm and tail rosettes. His body is painted blue and he is wearing a red breechclout. In addition, he is wearing beaded bow guards, calf bands and moccasins. In his hands, he is holding black scalp locks. A fringed and beaded pouch is hanging from his belt.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Scalp dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Woody Crumbo (script, lower right); Crumbo (printed, lower right)
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Native American ceremonial war dancer in full regalia. As he dances, he is facing the viewer with his right knee bent and raised at waist height and his lower leg slanted to the right. His left knee is bent with his foot on the floor. His left arm is bent and he is holding a scalp in his left hand. In the hand of his outstretched and raised right arm, he is holding a feathered fan. In addition to black body paint, he is wearing a feathered roach headdress, large feathered arm and tail rosettes, a long red breechclout, beaded bow guards, lower leg bands and moccasins. He is also wearing ankle bells.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Two seated figures with fans)
creator: Geionety, George
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of two Native American men seated and facing each other. Each one has feathers in his hair, orange paint on his face and a feathered beaded fan in his right hand. The man on the right is dressed in fringed buckskin and a blue blanket. The man on the left is wrapped in a pink and black blanket. On the ground behind each man is a box used to hold ceremonial objects.
condition: there is a groove about 1 3/4" long ending at the fan on the left, a dent near left edge; museum mounting

title: Eagle dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Woody Crumbo (script, lower right); Crumbo (printed, lower right)
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Native American eagle dancer in motion. He is facing the viewer with his head turned to the left. His legs are in a side lunge position with his right leg bent and his left straight. He is wearing feathered wing-like decorations on his arms. His right arm is curved over his head. His left arm is curved down to his left. He is wearing blue body paint with designs painted on his legs. In addition, he is wearing a feathered roach headdress, a beaded collar, beaded arm and lower-leg bands and beaded moccasins.

title: Buffalo dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Woody Crumbo (script, lower right); Crumbo (printed, lower right)
description: A silkscreen of a Plains Native American buffalo dancer wearing a buffalo hide complete with horns and a tail. He is wearing the horns as a headdress and the hide is hanging down his back. He is facing right as he dances with his right leg bent and raised at waist height. He is leaning back slightly and looking upward. The area around his eyes is painted with a red-and-white band and a red, blue and black design is painted down the outside of his legs. He is wearing a red breechclout and lower-leg wraps made out of buffalo fur. He is holding a knife in his right hand and a decorated shield on his left arm. This painting was done on a gray background.

subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
signature: Woody Crumbo (script, lower right); Crumbo (printed, lower right)

title: Dancers will bring rain
creator: Kloss, Gene
description: An etching of a Pueblo Ceremony. A line of female dancers, wearing the traditional one shoulder manta, are moving from an opening between the Pueblo buildings into the plaza. In the foreground, there are four spectators to the left and three to the right. The buildings of the Pueblo form the background for the scene. On the back: Summer Corn Dance, Etching and Drypoint (52), also #593 E & D, 1980, Ed. 25. On a hanging tag: Dancers Will Bring Rain, 1980, W 12 1/2 X HT 9 5/8.

title: Dreams are with me
creator: Henderson, Kathy
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A portrait of the head and shoulders of a Native American man with long black hair who is wearing face paint. He is facing the viewer and is wrapped in a black blanket that has a red and a white  stripe. These stripes are on his right shoulder. His face has white paint on the lower half of it and blue paint on the upper half. The blue paint forms two points that extend from his cheeks to his chin. The margin of the blue paint, where it meets the white, is outlined in red. Three large feathers are attached to the back of his head. One feather is hanging down toward his left shoulder and two feathers are hanging down toward his right shoulder. On the back of painting: # 600, "Dreams -- Are With Me", K. Henderson.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Lion of Judea
creator: Richard, Maxine
description: A black and white image of a seated lion facing the viewer's left with geometric shapes in the background. Framing this image is a band that says "Fenster Museum Jewish Art" with circular symbols under the lion. There are threads of gold applied at random over the image. At the bottom of the print is "A. P., Lion of Judea" in pencil.

title: Sweet talkin' man (study)
creator: Snidow, Gordon
description: A study used for a finished painting and a limited edition book. The study is of a man and a horse in a fenced area. The sorrel horse is facing right and watching as the man approaches him with a rope in his hand. The man is wearing a cowboy hat, a vest and chaps and he appears to be talking to the horse. This book and study were numbered 15 of a limited edition of 50. A study of different paintings was included with each book. Written on the bottom margin of the study is the phrase To my friends Maxine and Jack, Thank you for making my Gilcrease show the highlight of my life,  signed G. Snidow CA.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual Rendezvous exhibition, May 12, 1981. Gordon Snidow was the featured artist. Mr. Zarrow, representing his company Sooner Pipe and Supply, also purchased a sculpture, "Just A Pinch Between Your Teeth and Gum," at this exhibition. It was displayed at the corporate headquarters.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Pow-wow fancy dancer)
creator: Nevaquaya, Doc Tate
subject: Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of a male powwow dancer in full regalia. He is facing left and is playing a fully beaded flute that he is holding in his right hand. In his left hand, he is holding a feather dance fan. He is wearing beaded gauntlets, arm bands, chest straps, belt and ankle bands with fur hanging down. In addition, he is wearing a breechclout with two trailers, two bustles, and bands of bells around his legs just below the knees. His black hair is braided and he is wearing a roach headdress.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail bid at an R. G. Munn auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 4, 2001. This painting was one of six purchased at this auction.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Two male, one female Pueblo dancers)
creator: Secatero, John
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: John Secatero written on a feather (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of three Pueblo buffalo dancers consisting of two men and one woman. The woman is in the center of the painting and is facing left with her head turned toward the viewer. She is wearing a traditional handwoven embroidered one-shoulder dress and a red handwoven belt. She is holding two feathers in each hand. The male dancers on either side of her are wearing handwoven embroidered armbands and kilts, and buffalo headdresses. The handwoven garments are white with red, green, blue and black embroidery. The male dancers are holding rattles in their right hands and two feathers in their left hands. In addition, they are wearing bands of bells around their waists and lower legs. The dancer on the left is facing the viewer and the dancer on the right has his back to the viewer. All three dancers have their left foot raised as they dance.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail bid at an R. G. Munn Auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 4, 2001. This painting was one of six purchased at this auction, including two paintings by Fred Beaver, which were purchased for Ginger Kingman.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Silversmith)
creator: Tsihnahjinnie, Andy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
signature: Tsihnahjinnie with a drawing of a hogan (printed, lower right)
description: A painting of a Navajo silversmith at work. He is turned to the right with his head facing the viewer. He is seated cross-legged on the ground as he hammers a piece of silver that is laying on an anvil. He has a band tied around his forehead and is wearing a blue shirt and tan pants. Silver concha belts, silver horse bridle parts and silver necklaces are hanging on a bush behind him. There are sandstone molds on the ground in front of him and to his right. A fireplace for heating the silver is in front of him. A bellows is lying on the ground by his right knee.
condition: smudging and staining near bottom; smudging by the silversmith's right eyebrow; cardboard backing
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail bid at an R. G. Munn Auction, Albuquerque, NM, February 2, 2001. This painting was one of six purchased at this auction.

title: Navajo Indian weaver and silversmith at Monument Valley
creator: Tsihnahjinnie, Andy
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Navajo woman and a Navajo man. The woman is kneeling in front of a loom as she weaves a rug and the man is making silver jewelry using an anvil. The scene takes place outside in Monument Valley, Arizona. There is a bluff behind them and a tree to the left. The loom is hanging from a branch of the tree. The woman is wearing a traditional Navajo velvet blouse and gathered skirt and her hair is wrapped in a chongo. Her blouse is burgundy and her skirt is blue. The man is dressed in a blue shirt and gray pants. He is facing the right and the woman is facing the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Farm house kitchen
creator: Sanchez, Lawrence
description: A painting of the corner of a room that contains two windows and a porcelain sink. The sink is set in a crudely made green cabinet that has a plywood countertop. On the wall above the sink is a small cabinet with a box of corn flakes cereal on top of it. A dish, a tin can and a cooking kettle sit on the countertop to the left of the sink. A milk bottle is in the sink. A yellow dish pan, a knife, a glass mug, a paper cup and a can of scouring powder are on the countertop to right of the sink.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Three brothers
creator: Belindo, Dennis
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting of three men dancing, perhaps a powwow fancy war dance. They are dancing back to back, thus facing three different directions, with one facing the viewer. All three men are wearing roach-style headdresses with two feathers attached and red cloth capes. The man facing the viewer wears a bone hair pipe choker, a bone hair pipe breast plate, leather leggings, a red breechclout and beaded moccasins. Each dancer is holding a feathered staff, and the dancer facing the viewer has a beaded feather fan in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Voice of the drum circles the sun
creator: Hill, Joan
subject: Creek (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A stylized painting of a man facing the viewer in front of a black hillside. His black trousers and black coat blend in with the background and are not visible. He is wearing a wide-brimmed, high-crowned white hat, a black coat with a fur collar, a white shirt and two rows of conchos around his waist. A long white scarf is draped over his left arm, and he is holding a drumstick in his left hand. In his right hand, he is holding a drum, and he appears to be singing. The sky above the hill is red with a white moon on the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's Master Art Show, September 20, 1981. This painting received the Grand Award at the Five Civilized Tribes Museum's 1981 Master Art Show, September, 1981. On the painting stretcher: "'The Voice Of The Drum Circles The Sun' acrylic 32 X 36 Joan Hill Chea Se Quah 79 & 81 Creek & Cherokee." Taped to the back of the frame: "'The Voice Of The Drum Circles The Sun' Drums were believed to be sacred or mysterious having great power because of the spiritual nature attributed to music. The drum represented all of life's forces and its rhythm was symbolical of the rhythm of the entire universe the heart throb of all creation. Music marked every occasion of the Indian's life whether large or small, happy or sad, important or unimportant and no occasion was complete without the drum."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Old man with memories ("I was there")
creator: Annesley, Robert
subject: Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A portrait of a gray-haired man wearing a cowboy hat and a collared sheepskin jacket. He faces right. The horizon suggests cattle and a man on horseback.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, September 27, 1981. On the invoice: "Painting of Austin Doolittle, working cowboy from Seminole, Texas." From a phone call made by Jack Zarrow to Bob Annesley, February 8, 1999: Bob remembered the drawing and stated that the subject was Austin Doolittle of Seminole, Texas. At 76 years of age, he was the oldest working cowboy in Texas when the painting was done in 1981.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: War dance
creator: Sweezy, Carl
subject: Arapaho (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow fancy war dancer with his back to the viewer. His left hand is raised toward the upper left and his right hand, holding a feather fan, is pointed toward the lower right. His head is turned to the right. The dancer is wearing a red breechclout, a feather bustle, feathered arm bands, moccasins and a feathered roach headdress. Beneath the dancer, an arrow is painted, pointing toward the left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, February 8, 1992. Note in the file: "2/25/92 Information given to us by Linda Greever, Art Market, Tulsa, OK. title: Corn dance
creator: Naha, Raymond
subject: Hopi (culture or style)
description: A painting of three dancing figures wearing three different kachina masks. Each dancer is wearing embroidered handwoven breechclouts over shorts, neck ruffs and arm decorations made out of spruce boughs, and dance moccasins. Each dancer has a band of bells tied around his upper calves. The dancer on the left has his back to the viewer, the dancer in the middle faces the viewer, and the dancer on the right faces left.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market's Sale of Important Art, Tulsa, OK, April 12, 1991. This painting was one of six purchased at the time. Jeanne Snodgrass King, Tulsa, Oklahoma, previously owned this painting. It was a gift of appreciation to her from the Philbrook Museum Volunteers when she left the museum in 1968. The volunteers had purchased it at Philbrook's "Indian Annual." In the mid 1980s, Mrs. King sold it to Jack Wilson, a Tulsa geologist and avid collector of Native American art. Mr. Wilson later sold the majority of his collection at the Art Market's "Sale of Important Art," where the Zarrows bought it. On a On a sticker on the dust cover: "Raymond Naha 11 1/4 X 16 1/2 'Corn Dance,' watercolor. Purch. March 1991."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Fire dance
creator: Chee, Robert
subject: Navajo (culture or style)
description: A painting on black mat board of four men dancing around a fire. Three of the men have their skin painted blue and are wearing only breechclout and a scarf tied over their heads. The fourth man is fully dressed in a shirt, trousers and moccasins. His exposed skin is also painted blue. The three men in breechclouts are dancing around the fire, while the fourth man is dancing toward the right. Eight Navajo women, wrapped in blankets as they watch the dance, are in the background.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the Art Market's "Sale of Important Art," Tulsa, OK, March 7-21, 1991. This painting is one of six purchased at this sale.

description: A geometric abstract painting that includes Pueblo designs, three Koshari clown representations, and one female figure.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail from the Robert F. Nichols Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 1, 1994. This painting was one of four purchased, including another by Gutierrez and two by David Paladin. title: Sun Carrier
creator: Seely, Alice Warder
signature: Alice Warder Seely (script, On the back of the painting)
description: A somewhat abstract painting of a Northwest Coast Native American man in ceremonial regalia. He is wearing a bird helmet on his head and is holding a rattle and a bird carving, which are ceremonial objects typical of the Northwest coast.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

title: Untitled (Three dancing figures)
creator: Herrera, Velino Shije
subject: Zia
description: A painting of three crouched dancing figures facing left. The figure on the left is wearing a war bonnet, a green kilt with a concho belt, a belt of bells and moccasins. His body is painted blue and yellow. He is holding a painted shield in his left hand and a stone hatchet in his right. The figure in the center is wearing a roach headdress. His body is painted black with red stripes on his face. He is wearing a red breechclout and has a spear in his left hand. The figure on the right is wearing a war bonnet, a red kilt and moccasins. His body is painted blue and yellow, and he is holding a feather shield in his left hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via mail from James Conlon, Albuquerque, NM, March 10, 1992. On the dust cover: "Datus E Myers Artist Velino Shije; Velino Shije Herrera, Ma Pe Wi, oriole (or Red Bird) Zia Pueblo."

title: Fancy dancer
creator: Crumbo, Woodrow Wilson
subject: Potawatomi (culture or style)
description: A painting of a powwow fancy dancer dancing toward the viewer. He is wearing a buffalo headdress with a roach and eagle feathers attached to it and a red breechclout. He is also wearing a blue vest with matching gauntlets, leg bands and moccasins. Animal tails appear to be attached to his arm and leg bands. In his left hand, he is holding a shield, and in his right hand, a spear. As he dances, his left leg is kicked back, and his arms are raised.
condition: Some sun discoloration of painting surface; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Howard Huston of Hurst, TX, June 2, 1995. This painting was one of three purchased, including two by Joe Herrera. Howard Huston gave the Zarrows the following data: "Thurlow Laurance (compos. 'Waters of Minnetonka') met Woody and brought him to Wichita University for schooling and to illustrate a book of Indian melodies. Thurlow was head of the music dept. at the university. After Thurlow's death, his wife (Edna) had all the pictures that were left. (Thurlow had destroyed many of them while he was ill). Woody had given Edna several paintings (including this one). When she had to give up and go to a one-room apt., she got rid of everything - rugs, jewelry, pots etc. We (my sister and I - friends of hers) were given 3 paintings. One of them was done on a deer hide (we gave it back after we moved into a smaller place). Betty Crawford..."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: image: 14 5/8 x 10 5/8 in.; framed: 23 7/8 x 20 in.

title: Figures from buffalo ceremony
creator: Awa Tsireh
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two flat, static figures facing the viewer. The one on the left is a man, and the one on the right is a woman. The man is wearing a buffalo headdress and a tan kilt. In his left hand, he is holding a bow and arrow, and in his right hand, a gourd rattle. The woman is wearing a handwoven embroidered blouse and skirt. She is also wearing a rain sash around her waist and a large, bustle-like circle of feathers on her back. She is holding two feathers in each hand.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from James Conlon in Santa Fe, NM, September 1992. On the dust cover: "'Figures From Buffalo Ceremony' by Awa Tsireh or Alfonso Roybal, purchased 1992."

title: Drying pumpkins
creator: Bales, Jean
subject: Iowa
description: A painting of 15 women peeling and drying pumpkin rings. At the top of the painting, there are drying racks, and six women are hanging pumpkin rings on them. At the bottom, there are 10 women working with a pile of pumpkins. The pumpkins are green and white, though their meat is orange. In the middle area of the painting, two white dogs and two young girls are chasing one another.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Indian Paintbrush Gallery in Siloam Springs, AR, October, 27, 1980. On the dust cover: "About 1979-80? watercolor on rice paper, 'Drying Pumpkins' by Jean Bales Iowa."

title: Untitled (Crouching Apache warrior)
creator: Palmer, Ignatius
subject: Mescalero Apache
description: A painting of a Native American man dressed in a blue breechclout, leather leggings and high-topped moccasins or Apache boots. He is crouched down and appears to be moving left. His upper body is twisted right, and his head is facing right. He is holding a shield in his left hand and a spear in his right.

title: Coyote at the mall
creator: McMurtry, Robert
subject: Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of an indoor mall. There are seven familiar stores in the background, while in the foreground, there is a coyote dressed as a cowboy. Various cartoon characters are walking around outside the stores. The title of the painting, "Coyote at the mall," is painted at the bottom as part of a border. In the center of the painting, there are large spangles on pins attached to a storefront.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market, Tulsa, OK, September 9, 1991. This painting was one of four purchased at the time. The others were by Mootzka, Joe Herrera and Able Sanchez.

title: Peyote ceremony
creator: Momaday, Al
subject: Kiowa (culture or style)
description: A painting of two couples, each consisting of a man and a woman, seated on either side of a fire built on a Native American church altar with a peyote bud also on the altar. For each couple, the woman is in the foreground. The man is in the background but slightly nearer to the fire than the woman. The woman on the left is wearing a red shawl, and the man next to her is wrapped in a black blanket. Their heads are bowed, and they are each holding a beaded feather fan in their left hand. The woman on the right is wrapped in a black blanket, her head is bowed, and she is holding a beaded feather fan. The man on the right is wearing a buckskin shirt and is wrapped in a red blanket. His head is raised, and his hands are outstretched. He is holding a ceremonial rattle, a staff and a fan in his left hand. A peyote bud and three water birds are in the sky above the smoke from the fire.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Art Market's "Sale of Important Art," which was held March 7-21, 1991. This painting was one of six purchased at this sale. The others were by R. Hood, R. Chee, J. D. Roybal, R. Naha, and M. Lomakema. Previously, this painting was given to Jeanne Snodgrass (King) by Al Momaday while she was working at Philbrook Museum, Tulsa, OK. She later sold it to Native American art collector Jack Wilson of Tulsa, OK. When he broke up his collection, he sold the painting at the Art Market's Sale of Important Art in 1991, where it was purchased by the Zarrows. On the dust cover: "'Peyote Ceremony' by Al Momaday." On the sticker: "Al Momaday; 'Peyote Ceremony' 19 1/2" X 25" tempera."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Untitled (Native American man on lunging horse)
creator: Bosin, Blackbear
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American man riding a frightened gray horse that is frantically lunging or bucking in an attempt to escape a bog. The horse's right rear leg is stuck in the mud. The Native American man is struggling to stay on the horse. His hair is braided, and he is wearing a red breechclout and moccasins. A shield hangs across his chest. He is using a buffalo hide as a saddle. A spear lies in the mud, almost under the horse's feet.
condition: slight water stains right side; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Robert P. Clinton and his mother, Mrs. T. P. Clinton, of Tulsa, OK, December 30, 1998. This painting was one of two by Bosin the Zarrows purchased from the Clintons. The Clintons had purchased the paintings from the artist.

title: Trail marker
creator: Bosin, Blackbear
subject: Kiowa (culture or style); Comanche (culture or style)
description: A painting of two Native American men on horses. The man on the right is facing right and is wearing a white buffalo headdress with feather-trimmed trailers. In his right hand, he is holding the horse's war bridle rein and a beaded pipe bag. In his left hand, he is holding a staff decorated with feathers. Both his boot moccasins and the knife scabbard at his waist are beaded. The man on the left is facing left, as is his horse. He is wearing a brown fur hat, a red breechclout and moccasins. He is also wearing hair bands, gauntlets and a belt, all of which are beaded. The horse's nose bands are also beaded. He is holding a staff in his right hand and a bow and arrows in a scabbard in his left hand. He is looking to the right. A decorated buffalo skull is in the foreground.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Robert P. Clinton and his mother, Mrs. T. P. Clinton, of Tulsa, OK, December 20, 1998. This painting is one of two by Bosin the Zarrows purchased from the Clintons. The Clintons had purchased the paintings from the artist.

title: Snow bird dance
creator: Vigil, Romando
subject: San Ildefonso
description: A painting of two Pueblo dancers facing left. One looks to the left while the other has their head turned toward the viewer. They each hold a rattle in their right hand and a bow in their left hand. They each wear a fur ruff around their neck, a white shirt, a turquoise necklace, a white handwoven and embroidered kilt, a rain sash, white knit stockings, dance moccasins and bells around their calves. There is a stylized bird in the sky and a decorative design across the bottom of the painting.
condition: one small stain, lower right side; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Gallery 10, Scottsdale, AZ, January 13, 1991. This painting was one of seven purchased by the Zarrows at the time, including two others by Romando Vigil and one each by J. D. Roybal, T. Vigil, Duane Dishta, and Popovi Da.

title: Corn dance
creator: Blue Eagle, Acee
subject: Creek (culture or style); Pawnee (culture or style)
description: A painting of four Pueblo figures, two males and two females. The three figures on the left are facing right, while the figure on the far right is facing left. The man on the far left is dressed in Plains Native American style clothing, consisting of fringed buckskin and a war bonnet. He is holding a large drum with his left hand and is beating it with the drumstick he is holding in his right hand. To his right is a dancing female figure dressed in traditional Pueblo ceremonial clothing. She is holding two feathers in each of her hands. To her right is a dancing male figure wearing a buffalo headdress, a kilt, a sash and dance moccasins. He holds a bow in his left hand and a rattle in his right. The figure on the far left is female. She wears a blue blouse, a multicolored striped skirt, plaid pants and moccasins. She holds a bow in her left hand and a spruce branch in her right. She appears to be singing.
condition: torn and wrinkled, lower right side; museum mounting
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Wes Gan of Native American Art, Tulsa, OK, March 17, 1992. Mr. Wes Gan received the painting from K. E. Gan, Bartlesville, OK, who had purchased it from Mae Abbot. Mae Abbot, a close friend of Acee Blue Eagle, received the painting from him.

title: Forest fire
creator: McCombs, Solomon
subject: Creek (culture or style)
description: A painting of a forest fire burning in the background, while animals and people flee in the foreground. The animals and people are moving toward the right. From left to right, there are a pair of foxes, two bears standing on their hind legs by a tree, a woman carrying a baby, a man running with a green tree branch in his hands, and a running deer.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from D. F. Henry Company, Tulsa, OK, December 12-15, 1980. This painting was exhibited at the Gilcrease Museum in the Fred Beaver/Solomon McCombs Memorial Exhibition held March 7-April 19, 1981. The Zarrows were one of the sponsors of this exhibition. On a sticker at the top of the dust cover: "Solomon McCombs (1913-1980) 'Forest Fire'; casein, 1976; collection: Maxine and Jack Zarrow." Glued to the dust cover is a newspaper article: "Creek Tribal Leader Dies," November 18, 1980.

title: Dog Soldier's challenge
creator: West, W. Richard (Walt Richard)
subject: Cheyenne (culture or style)
description: A painting of a Native American warrior wearing an elaborate headdress. He is facing the viewer and is standing with his legs spread and his right arm raised. In his right hand, he is holding a bow and arrows. In his left hand, he is holding a spear decorated with feathers. Its tip is resting on a scarf-like trailer, also decorated with feathers. One end of the trailer is hanging over his left shoulder and across his chest. He is wearing beaded leggings and a red breechclout. A fur belt is hanging around his hips.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gentry Gallery, Tulsa, OK, October 31, 1980. The exhibition was held as a Native American scholarship fundraiser for the Oklahoma Indian Art Program. The exhibition was sponsored by the Gentry Gallery and the McDonnell Douglas Management Club. The Zarrows purchased four paintings at this exhibition. In addition to this painting, they purchased works by Jimmie Fife, Burgess Roye, and Jeanne Rorex.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Ribbon dance - Green corn ceremony
creator: Pahsetopah, Paul
subject: Osage (culture or style); Cherokee (culture or style)
description: A painting of five dancing women with long multicolored ribbons in their hair and hanging down their backs. The women move to the right. Eight men, who have their backs to the viewer, are wearing wide-brimmed hats and are sitting on benches under a brush-covered shelter. These men, as well as three other men in the foreground, are watching the dancers. Between the two groups of men, a little girl is standing and sucking her thumb as she also watches the dancers.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist, March 11, 1981. On a piece of cardboard glued to the dust cover: "'Ribbon Dance - Green corn Ceremony' 81 Paul PahseTopah; permanent watercolor and casein; Euchee-Creek woodland- 5 Civ Tribes; Euchee-Creek Woodland; To Maxine and Jack Zarrow Best Regards Paul PahseTopah 3/11/81."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Zia eagle dancers
creator: Medina, Rafael
subject: Zia
description: A painting of two dancers wearing eagle headdresses and eagle feather capes across their backs and arms. They are wearing handwoven embroidered kilts and handwoven sashes. The dancer on the right is facing left, and he is dancing with his left foot on the ground and his right foot raised, arms outstretched. The dancer on the left is facing the viewer with his head turned to the right and is crouched down with his arms extended. There is a ceramic effigy bowl on the ground between the dancers, and spirit images of the dancers changing into eagles appear to come out of the bowl and rise into the sky. Two ceramic pots are on the ground on either side of the dancers.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Tom Woodard at his home in Santa Fe, NM, March 1992. Mr. Woodard had purchased the painting from Rafael Medina in 1976, when Woodard was trying to collect enough of Rafael Medina's paintings for a one-man show.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Dancing before the hunt
creator: Hunt, Wolf Robe
subject: Acoma
description: A painting of two rows of 10 Pueblo dancers. Seven are wearing headdresses representing animals. The top row consists of four dancers. Three are wearing antelope headdresses, and one is wearing a mountain sheep headdress. The dancer on the far left is facing right, while the other three face left. The bottom row consists of four dancers and two drummers. The dancer on the far left is facing left and is wearing a deer headdress. To his right are the two drummers. The dancer to the right of them is wearing a buffalo headdress and is facing right. The dancer to the right of him is a woman who is also facing right. The dancer on the far right is wearing a buffalo headdress and is facing right.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from Wes Gan at Native American Art, Tulsa, OK, May 11, 1998. According to Mr. Gan, the artist sold this painting to Field's Fine Art, Tulsa, OK. Field's sold it to Bob Matheson, Tulsa, OK. From Mr. Matheson, the painting went to Ron Williams, Atlanta, GA. Mr. Wes Gan obtained it from Mr. Williams. On the dust cover: "From ARTIST: to Fields Fine Arts, Tulsa, OK to Bob Matheson, Tulsa, OK to Ron Williams, Atlanta, GA. 'Dancing Before The Hunt' circa: mid 1960's; ARTIST: Wolf Robe Hunt (Acoma) from Native American Art - Wes Gan.... Medium - tempera-casein on 300 lb. rag paper; conservation framed - acid free."
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Hopi with moata
creator: Cannon, T. C.
subject: Caddo; Kiowa (culture or style); Choctaw (culture or style)
description: A portrait of a Hopi woman wearing a traditional hairstyle. The woman is shown from the waist up, and she is facing the viewer. She is wearing a handwoven black blanket, or perhaps a dress, and a striped purple shawl. She is wearing a multistrand choker around her neck. The area behind her is covered with horizontal stripes of cream and gold. This piece is T. C. Cannon's last signed woodcut, circa 1970.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Gifted to Jack and Maxine Zarrow by Geri and Stan to celebrate the Zarrows' 50th anniversary, 1997.

title: Adrina
creator: Carlson, George
signature: Carlson 1991 (printed on the back of the left upper arm)
description: A sculpture of the chest, head and shoulders of a young girl with her arms raised over her head forming a circle, resembling a ballet arm position. Her fingers are interlaced. Her hair is in a ponytail and her head is slightly bowed and turned to her left. Her right arm almost touches the back of her head. The base is black marble.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow at the Gilcrease Museum's annual Rendezvous exhibition, Tulsa, OK, April 30, 1994. The featured artists for Rendezvous '94 were Bob Kuhn, painter, and George Carlson, sculptor. In addition to this sculpture, the Zarrows purchased Mr. Carlson's "Interlude."

title: Seven faces
creator: Haney, William Woodrow, Jr.
subject: Seminole; Creek (culture or style)
description: A sculpture of seven faces starting 5 1/2 inches from the base. The faces are on the sides with the front being flat, and they are one above the other. On the left, there are three faces. The lowest one is facing the viewer, the middle one is facing the left and the one at the top looks up and slightly toward the viewer. On the right, there are four faces. The lowest is turned slightly toward the viewer and directly behind him is a face that is not seen from the front and is facing right. Above the lower two faces, there is a face that is turned to the right and the highest face on this side is a face that is at the behind the head of the uppermost face on the left. Carved on the front, just under the uppermost head, there are eight stars arranged in ascending rows of four, three, and one.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from William Haney, Jr., around the same time they purchased Haney's sculpture, "Legend of the Owl," October 22, 1979.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
size: sculpture: 24 1/2 in. height x 11 1/2 in. width x 6 3/4 in. diameter

title: Simen's Torah (Simchat Torah celebration)
creator: Roth, Uri
description: An olive wood sculpture of two figures with heads that are out of proportion with the rest of their bodies. They are each holding rolled up scrolls, perhaps Torahs, on their right sides. The sculpture is somewhat crudely carved. They appear to be speaking or singing. The bottom is not level and the sculpture tends to rock.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Gifted to Jack and Maxine Zarrow by their daughter, Kathy Zarrow. Ms. Zarrow purchased the sculpture in Israel, December 8, 1976.

title: Untitled (Welded steel screen with petroglyph figures)
creator: Weigel, Doug
description: A steel petroglyph screen that was mounted on the Zarrow's backyard fence. It consists of two squares, one inside the other. There are two petroglyph figures consisting of a Kokopelli on the left and a Hopi maiden on the right. Each figure is in one of the upper corners of the outer square. A long-tailed deer or elk-like figure in the middle of the upper line of the inside square. Another petroglyph figure is on the bottom line of the inside square, slightly to the right of center. A curving line runs from the lower left of the outer square to the upper right of the outer square. There are two petroglyph figures on this line consisting of a horned snake, or spiral, while the other three are zigzag lines.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow via special order from Doug Weigel through the New Trends Gallery, Santa Fe, NM, February 4, 1991.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives

title: Legend of the owl
creator: Haney, William Woodrow, Jr.
subject: Seminole; Creek (culture or style)
signature: Wm Haney '79 (printed below the man's right knee)
description: A sculpture of an owl with a ring in its left ear and its claws grasping the head and left shoulder of a kneeling man on the left. The owl's tail is touching a tree stump at the back of the sculpture. The man is holding his left hand palm up, and he is resting it on the back and head of a woman whose head is covered with a shawl. The woman is kneeling on the right and she has her hands over her face.

title: Animal spirits
creator: Joe, Orlando C., Sr.
subject: Navajo (culture or style); Ute (culture or style)
signature: O C Joe CA '97 (printed on the bottom right side)
description: An abstract flat sculpture of the head and shoulders of two Yei, one above the other. The upper one has a blue square face and the lower one has an orange round face. The square-headed one has two feathers at the top of his head, one bronze and one green. He is also wearing large square earrings and a necklace to match. The round-headed one has three feathers, two brown and one green, and is wearing turquoise drop earrings and a double strand of turquoise beads. There is a rattle on the round-headed one's right shoulder. Brass label: "Autumn Spirits" by Orland C. Joe.
scope and contents: The Zarrow Collection features a vast array of artwork primarily by Native American artists from several federally recognized tribal nations. This artwork was collected from museums, exhibitions, and art galleries across the nation by Maxine and Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Oklahoma.
provenance: Purchased by Jack and Maxine Zarrow from the artist at the Gilcrease Museum's annual Rendezvous exhibition, Tulsa, OK, May 1, 1999.
source: Zarrow Collection, Oklahoma State University Archives
